title: Meh
text: I usually love DiCamillo’s books. This one was alright but rather far fetched. It also ended very abruptly.

title: It was just....OK!
text:
If you are a Patterson Lover, and have not grown tired of the "I am Alex Cross and all my friends are either crazed killers who I am tracking and don't know it...or I have a ton of problems and yet still manage to solve the crime"...this tale is for you. After a much needed break [I had decided that I needed to give Alex Cross a little rest and enjoy some of Patterson's other works,like the winged people....now that was interesting and I enjoyed it] I picked up in the series where I left off....Big Bad Wolf. Unfortunately, after reading it I felt a little out of sorts and had to ask myself the question..."just what do I think of this novel?" I really had to search within myself and decide what was it that I just didn't get? Or is it that I got it, but wasn't sure if I liked it?

Well for starters we still have the ever present Alex Cross, who has left the DC PD and decided to go Federal (FBI);then there's "Mama Nana" or whatever he calls his mother, who quietly states the obvious;his friend, Sampson who makes a cameo appearance and states that he is expecting a child; his absent girlfriend (Jamilla) who appears to be a little too mysterious for my taste at first, but appears periodically throughout the thriller (encouraging phone calls no less, hope she doesn't turn out to be a killer); Kyle (his psychotic ex-friend who use to work for the FBI); and a few others. Patterson also introduces new characters, like Monty (FBI computer expert, single with kids) and Mahoney (an eager partner who loves the excitement of having a partner who is willing to think out of the box....so I am sure he will either ultimately be killed or be the crooked FBI agent that is being paid off by the Wolf). Unfortunately, most of my rating is based solely on the love I have for Patterson's creativity and not so much about my love of the book. Although there was A LOT of potential (I loved the mystery surrounding who the Wolf really is) it was a little confusing. Patterson spent the first have of the novel introducing a sadistic, kidnapping couple and killed them early on. He introduced a concept of white slavery among the rich...which was interesting, but then it seemed forced by introducing so many other "bad things" that the wolf was involved in....it just all seemed a little FORCED. Oh and another thing, because I am not in love with the character of Alex's baby's mother, Christine, I did not enjoy her reappearance after being absent for over a year. I didn't care about her as a character and wondered why she was coming back. It just seemed that while Alex was trying to solve his first case while joining the FBI, he just didn't need the drama surrounding his exgirlfriend's decision to claim their son. Of course I know, and you will too when and if you complete it, that the whole book is set up for the sequel, but I am not sure that I want to read it. OK, I probably will!

title: Quick, easy read
text: Despite all the odds, the reader hopes for the best. This story minimizes the legal work and highlights a faulty legal system. None, other than our heroine, believes the underdog.

title: Magnificent book, absolutely horrible edition
text:
If I were to list the favorite books of my life time of reading -- a list that would include many thousand books -- "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" would be either first or second, vying with Henry Roth's incredible "Call it Sleep". Bottom line, I love this book -- have read it (and listened to it) at least eight or nine times and I'm not done yet. It's my turn-to book when I want the comfort of reading something I know I love.

So why two stars? I bought this particular book for a young friend who doesn't read all that much - she's the "Why are you giving me a book? I already have one" kind of person. But I thought that if ever there was a book that would hook her from the first page, that she would glory in, identify with, day in, day out, this would be it. How could anyone not love, not revel in, the tale of Frannie's incredible life?

Sorry to tell you, that didn't happen -- and I'm still convinced the problem is this particular edition. The book itself is very thick -- which I personally love, but which scared the bejesus out of my young friend. But compounding that, the print is SO TINY!! Why would a publisher do that? Put WIDE margins on the pages, and make the print so small even I -- 20-20 vision! -- had to struggle with it?

The result? It's an intimidating-looking book: so many pages, such little bitty tiny small print. If I'd SEEN this edition myself, I'd never have bought it for my friend -- I could see right away that this would look was too formidable for a non-compulsive reader, no matter how good the story itself was.

Too bad, too bad. I still think this is a great "intro" book for a person who hadn't yet acquired the reading bug, but most definitely not this edition. There are a lot of different editions out there -- pick one of them that LOOK inviting. An edition that has a picture or something on the cover -- AND the traditional back-cover blurb about what this story is all about, something else this edition lacks.

If anyone could make "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" look uninviting, this publisher managed it. What a shame!

title: A personal political diatribe or a relevant medical-political thriller? You decide.
text:
Michael Palmer died unexpectedly a few months ago in October of 2013. “Resistant” is the author’s twentieth and final novel. It stands alone, but it’s the third book in the author’s Dr. Lou Welcome series. The novel was complete and at the publisher before he died.

I was curious to read his final novel. In the past, I’d enjoyed the rich medical details, tight plotting, suspense, and intrigue of his earlier works. The author’s untimely death saddened me and reawakened my interest in his work. I was curious how his writing might have changed over the years. I knew that he was a skilled commercial storyteller of unapologetically formulaic medical thrillers. It was a genre that has always held my interest, but lately, there seemed to be so many new and talented writers in this arena, I had no time or interest to return to Michael Palmer. Not until now.

What I discovered immediately about this Lou Welcome series is that the author had branched out into a crossover genre half way between political and medical thrillers. The novel is still packed with his signature, testosterone-filled action, suspense and medical detail, but there is a major controversial political issue at its core. It’s the same issue that’s currently dividing our Nation. If you’re on the liberal side of this issue, this book may please you. If you’re on the conservative side, it will probably make you angry. Whatever side you’re on, I’m sure you’ll recognize that the politics at its core is a gross distortion that adds nothing to the political debate.

“Resistant” is about a small clandestine group of ultra-fanatic right-wing conservatives. They call themselves the Society of One Hundred Neighbors. They came into existence in the era of FDR and Ayn Rand. Currently, they exist to rid the United States of all entitlement programs (especially Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid) and free the country from what they see as the death grip of bankrupting debt. They’re prepared to go to any ends necessary to achieve their goal, including biological terrorism. Their new weapon is the Janus bacterium, a germ very similar to streptococcus pyogens, the flesh-eating bacteria that causes necrotizing fasciitis. They’ve unleashed the pathogen in target hospitals around the country. The government is managing the crisis in secret to contain public panic. The government calls the terrorist weapon the Doomsday Germ. The trouble is, the bacteria have gotten the upper hand. They’re mutating. The Society’s new antibiotic agent can no longer contain them.

So how does the author’s main character, Dr. Lou Welcome, get involved in the crisis and manage to be at the focal point of its resolution? Well, you’ll have to read the book to find out, but I assure you: the plot is utterly unbelievable. But heck, this is supposed to be blockbuster commercial fiction. It may be over-the-top and downright silly in parts, but it kept me reading and entertained. Despite the ugly political distortions and exaggerated two-dimensional characters, I felt there was enough decent commercial fiction, suspense, and tension to earn it at least three stars.

After finishing the book, I reread a few Michael Palmer obituaries and was stunned to realize how much Lou Welcome mirrors the author’s own personal real life story. Both Dr. Lou Welcome and Dr. Michael Palmer had early careers as emergency room doctors; both men became addicted to pain killers, drugs, and alcohol and, partially as a result, lost their beloved wives to divorce; both men were disciplined by the medical profession and ended up serving in a volunteer capacity for a physicians-wellness organization assisting medical personnel with their substance abuse problems; both men eventually went into private practice in internal medicine. But the resemblance ends there. Lou Welcome is, of course, younger, brighter, stronger, more athletic, a greater risk taker, a more loyal friend, a more supporting father, etc. You get the picture? Lou Welcome is a fictional hero; he’s also, certainly, Michael Palmer’s tailor-made alter ego.

As a medical doctor with a long history of substance abuse and recovery, Michael Palmer has been quoted as saying that he started writing suspense thrillers as a type of long-term personal therapy. “When it comes to writing,” he said, “I loved the feeling of being in control when my life was not.” Well, none of us are in control of the current political debate that is dividing our Nation. I’m sure no matter which side you’re on, you’re probably immensely frustrated with your inability to control the situation. Obviously in this, his last book, Palmer was able to craft a plot that allowed him to not only be the heroic star of his own fictional world, but also a man capable of slaying his own private political dragon. I’m sure he derived a great deal of satisfaction writing this book. You decide if you will enjoy reading it.

Personally, I’m pleased I read it. If nothing else, it gave me a glimpse of psychological insight into the real-life author behind the book.

Dr. Michael Palmer, may you rest in peace along with your alter ego, Dr. Lou Welcome.

title: Perhaps suitable for entry level engineers?
text:
It may be suited for entry entry level engineers, and they find it an interesting read. I didn't learned anything, I am afraid, and was irritated at times when I disagreed with authors opinion that was being passed off as facts.

What bothered me the most is the lack of rigor, for instance, he advocates for incremental design which costs 10-20% and if you don't it will make you 10%-20% slower after some point. The only motivation a graph with no units. It may matter if is 10% or 20%, as that is after all a factor of 2. Also, it's not really clear that once in a while 10% investment, let's call it 45 minutes is a very different cost than a recurring daily 45 minute overhead due to cost being a mess. I don't have any data to dispute the numbers, btw, but on the other hand, I have not seen any studies to support it either, and the author does not tell us where he is getting this from.

His advise of avoiding lots of small functions as it means you will be bouncing all over the place to understand the code is not necessarily wrong. It adds lots of boiler plate, for example. Using an argument from the book itself, however, you could argue that good names and comments would mean you didn't need to read those lower level functions. The counter argument is that smaller functions are much easier to unit test. Then you have the unit test vs integration test discussion of course.

There are 3 chapters on comments. Why?! I am towards the "good code is self-documenting" end of the spectrum, although I would say a lot of comments is often (but certainly not always) a code smell that suggest refactoring using better names, extracting code to function etc. I do like how he describes good comments as either lower or higher level than the code.

The text editor example that runs through most of the book becomes trite. What I find way more interesting is when he talks about his experience with TCL (design mistakes, or the benefits derived from unit test suite), or towards the end RAMCloud and a specific implementation detail.

title: Not a favorite
text: The plot was interesting, but this book needed an editorial overhaul in a big way.  So much of it is written in a very passive voice which doesn't match the story at all.  Maybe it's because I'm not English, but I can't imagine a senior major crimes detective saying, "Oh, dear" in just about any situation, least of all one that relates to murders. It also reads as if someone told the author to add more details so I could skip entire paragraphs that added nothing to the story.  I think this author could be quite successful but he needs to find a better editor IMO.

title: Terrible tale, terrible characters, terrible ending
text: I absolutely hated reading this “memoir”. I finished it because my book club will be discussing it, but I wish I hadn’t. Apart from not being able to connect to a single character, the writing is thin. The story itself has a sensational air about it and it seems a bit far-fetched. But if it’s all true, then I am angry at the fact that no one—not the neighbors, the grandparents, nor the clergy or medical staff —ever questioned the family about the abuse nor reported it to the authorities. True, the parents avoided most authority figures, but others knew what was going on in that family everyday, including Tara. I understand that she was a victim when she was a child living in the home, but when she left and finally sought counseling in college, the bishop and later her counselor both knew about the abuse that was STILL ongoing in the family. When I read about the dog, I almost threw up. I’m very upset that in her EDUCATED path to enlightenment, Tara forgot about her sister-in-law and children, and other family members who were trapped in the abusive dysfunction. Achieving a Ph.D, obviously did not give her the fortitude to help those family members who could not help themselves. I can’t help but wonder...what is your brother Shawn doing right now, Tara?

title: Is has as bad an ending to any book that I have ever ...

title: Great series with some additional work
text: By no means am I a professional book critic or do I claim to be. I am just a lover of a good book mainly romance novels. I started the first book on Thursday and was through by Friday. That same Friday I started book two and was done by Saturday. I am now currently on the third book so that should give you an idea of how quick of a read these novels are. I really enjoyed reading these and deciphering what would occur next. However, please bare in mind that these books contain some MAJOR grammatical errors and printing mess up’s in the text. For the amount of money one novel cost and the number of novels in this series I found this to be very irritating and sloppy to say the least. I also found that some of the character issues were drawn out beyond what was necessary which would and did cause many readers to not continue after the second or even first book. I managed to over look these issues because I was already invested in the story line. I do plan on continuing with more books from this series but at these price points it’ll be drawn out to treating myself to 3 books a piece over a duration of months.

title: Nonsensical  words  useless for vocabulary
text:
Advantage: This book is truly extra large print, with the word search grid on one page and the word list on a separate page.

Disadvantage: The words seem to be chosen via a computer program. Many are simply the names of foreign cities such as "Kioto" and "Fukui." These have no translation into Spanish except as the city in Japan. Likewise "borne " is an English word which should be "suportada" in Spanish. I found all of these errors, and more on the FIRST page. Look for another source.

title: Ok but a little slower
text:
Oddly there are very few biblical fiction books that take place during biblical times or involve people of the Bible. It must be Amish fiction sells too well. That or authors seem to be nervous of being termed heretics.

With the first Noah book I enjoyed (Grade - B) and I like Chaffey's writing. Noah feels like a real person. He goes through character development. You understand his feelings and motivation. All the things you're supposed to do in a story. In this book, we pick back up with Noah from his just married happy ending. Oh and running away from the crazy princess who loves snake gods.

Throughout the book, Noah is written as being more of a leader and husband and friend. There are a lot of his personal aspects that are enjoyable to read. He also faces doubt and indecisiveness at times. Since we know the end story, this growth of Noah is really nice to see. He's not perfect and he's not holier-than-thou. The supporting cast of characters is interesting with Noah's friends being well written and sees Noah as a leader of the group. However, it's not like the hang on his every word and always need to be around him. There's a character who kind of gets a hero's speech in the middle of the book and it was nice that a supporting character could have that spotlight. The plot makes sense of where it's going and there are some neat highpoint scenes that are fun to read.

What the story had working against it was time factors. We Noah leads a long life but the jump in years of hundreds is really a big thing to do. This isn't like a character needing to advance in age by "5 years later" to get to their next plot point. Nothing happened of note to Noah in the 600 year time gap? On the other end of the spectrum, there is a lot of meandering plotting that happens. Some of this is the result of the slow travel by boats but there is a lot of travel to one place then back home and then back to the one place again and then off to a side trip. Noah's wife also feels like just a side character with kind of the normal thinking you'd probably guess she would have. It would have been interesting to have her challenging Noah's ideas or turning Noah to a correct understanding of God's character. She not a bad character but she just falls into a normal side character. The villains also aren't that well presented. It's the typical villains get power and so now they act crazy growth. It would have been neat to see pagan leaders develop the system of worship without being on the verge of madness and show that while the evil is growing to show the need for the Flood, they are people. They feel more like bad guy archetype characters than characters who are bad.

Overall, a decent read with some slow parts in the middle and some location changes that happen quickly that I'm not sure how certain characters get to where they're at. But with the knowledge that the Flood is coming, we know not all these characters can be with us for long and some neat plot points make it a good read and will want to continue the journey. Final Grade - C+

title: Not all about Beck
text: Warning: If you are a true fan who is interested in reading about Beck, you may be disappointed with this book. "Playing with Matches mostly concentrates on his grandfather Al Hansen. This was annoying. I got this book because I'm a true fan who wants to learn and get inside the head of beck which I thought this book would do. There is a short interview with beck but like I said, it centers on his grandfather. I'm sure Al Hansen is an honorable, talented, and creative man who means the world to Beck, and maybe there is a book out there about him but that's not who I was interested in reading about. One other criticism I have is that although there is some great illustrations of Becks artwork, there is no explanation of what any of it is or what any of it means, so you end up looking at his artwork that pretty much has no meaning to the reader. I will not discourage any fans by telling them not to buy this...they still may find this book an entertaining read. For me though, I'll pass this one onto friends that are fans of Beck.

title: A beautiful model at the pentacle of her career leaps to ...
text:
<I>Cuckoo's Calling</I> was interesting right from the start. A beautiful model at the pentacle of her career leaps to her death, the tragedy extensively splashed over every television, magazine and website. From there the narrative is shared from two very different perspectives. Robin Ellacott, a young woman recently moved to London and more importantly, over the moon excited about her new engagement to her longtime boyfriend Matthew. Cormoran Strike (who just goes by Strike) a detective who’s business and personal life is spiraling out of control.

I don’t know exactly what changed but I became less enthusiastic about reading it. Normally I JUMP at any opportunity to sit and loose myself in a novel; also I have a personal goal to read at least 50 pages a day. However, I was content reading a chapter a day of Cuckoo. The characters are well developed and I had no clue “who did it,” yet I still wasn't excited to sit and read more. I think the ground work is laid with this series though and the next book will be more attention grabbing throughout

title: Western-novel fans only
text: I bought this Western novel because I got "hung up" on Western themes for some reason.  I'm a HUGE Lonesome Dove fan.  One of the best books ever.  But most Westerns are just Westerns -- not very good, in my opinion.  So . . . The Searchers might be excellent for Western-novel fans, but it won't be good at all for fans of literary fiction.  Ditto for the movie.  The movie with John Wayne suffers from early-day production, of course, but taking that into account, it's still not very good.

title: Not Completely Hopeless
text:
Evie is a 24-year-old who has run away from graduate school, her family, her boyfriend and all of her acquaintances. She's a bit of a stray. Evie was once kicked out of yoga class for staring, and in graduate school she developed a cocaine habit.

Evie pays tuition to become a dog trainer at The Mountaintop School For Dogs, which is run by a handful of ex-nuns. But first, she must become acclimated by spending time at the nearby Inn, managed by Mrs. Auburchon. There she makes the acquaintance of a teenager nicknamed "Giant George," as well as many rescued dogs.

The human characters in this book seem to be part dog, and the dogs seem to be somewhat human.

Since I've not read any other books by Ellen Cooney, I do not know if the free-association style is typical of her writing, or if it is used to show how Evie processes information.

However, all does not seem completely hopeless -- Evie does experience growth.

One thing I really did like about this story was the way the characters accept each other despite their mannerisms and eccentricities.

title: Don't be fooled by all the positive reviews
text:
Very over rated. It is a collection of CLI commands organized broadly eg. UNIX, Windows, Wireshark, NMAP. If you have had a job as a SA for a few years, you likely already almost everything in this book. Whats more, each command is only followed by a very short (3-6 word) description. So, if you don't already know what its used for, you probably still wont.

This book is targeted at people who don't have Google available and don't have time to RTFM. What a pathetic assumption. StackOverflow or StackExchange would offer better results, and the man(ual) pages generally include a good examples. Instead of this book, I recommend that you actually RTFM.

title: Typical celebrity biography
text: I love Paul Anka & have seen him perform many times over the years.  His autobiography goes into detail about his career and his friendships with other celebrities, which is interesting, but there is not much detail about his personal life in this book.

title: Something out of sync
text: The biggest disappointment for me in this psychological thriller was the unconvincing portrayal of the heroine, Dr. Anna Fox. The author is a male, but he chooses to tells this story through his main character who is a woman. Only thing is, nothing about her portrayal as a female is at all female to me. Nothing rings true, not even a little bit. Nothing maternal,where maternal is called for, nothing sexy about her in any detail of the plot where such would be expected,  nothing soft, simply bogus. Even her appearance is somehow out of sync with what we know. She is 30-something, but in every description I’m seeing a septuagenarian, or older. Very weird choices have been made by the author . Also, his overdosing us with her alcohol and drug habit is cloying. Enough already!  I get it; she uses substance to get through having been traumatized by events, but at the rate we witness her imbibing and drugging, she would not even be able to notice anything from her windows, were she even able to remain conscious enough to see out of them, and yet, the author asks us to suspend  our logic as he wants us to believe him as much as she wants to convince the police that she saw what she saw. All too tedious and really got hideously in the way of what could have been a pretty good read. I just did not like this book. No literary merit here that I could find. This plot is pretty conventional, so at the end of the day, to be outstanding, an author would have to really work on character development and details presented in a fresh and lyrical way,

title: Too violent for me
text: I really enjoyed the first Asher Benson book and promptly bought the second.  But this one was just too violent for me.  Seemed like hardly a page escaped having corpses strewn everywhere.  And so many of them were innocent citizens - couldn't even get angry with them and justify the deaths.  I liked Asher's personal struggle, but will not be buying any more of the series because I don't like that many gory details.  Might as well go watch Nightmare on Elm Street.

text: While starting with wonderful character depth and analysis the further the plot developed the meaning and depth faded. For a mystery many loose ends and rich sub plots left to wither. And FAR too long. I felt cheated. An excellent writer who got carried away with an obscure form. The star charts Meant nothing to me.

title: A quirky, too short personal history
text: Jonathen Franzen's personal history is more a short collection of slightly disorganized life happenings than what one would usually expect in a memoir. He begins with the story of the sale of his mother's house after her death, located in "just right" Webster Groves, Missouri, where he grew up. His goal to obtain the highest possible price doesn't work out entirely as planned. Chapter Two, My Ponies, concerns Snoopy, with whom he felt a certain "kinship," and Peanuts comic strip creator Charles Schultz. Joy Breaks Through follows the antics of his teen youth group members, of which he shares some great words of wisdom (p 113): "Adolescence is best enjoyed without self-consciousness, but self-consciousness, unfortunately, is its leading symptom," and "You're miserable and ashamed if you don't believe your adolescent troubles matter, but you're stupid if you do." More on his teens follows in Centrally Located, especially the details of some high school pranks (complete with sketches). Learning German abroad is main subject of The Foreign Language. My Bird Problem contains a bit on romance and marriage, his changing awareness of and concern about the environment, and, likely the favorite part for birders, funny anecdotes about bird sightings at the Santa Ana Wildlife Refuge as well as his experiences as a bird watcher on Hat Island. Good as is, but fans will likely be left wanting more. Similarly satisfying: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius by Dave Eggers and Me Talk Pretty One Day by David Sedaris.

title: A slasher film lovers dream in the form of a book
text:
Noelle Ihli’s “The Thicket” is a slasher film lovers dream in the form of a book. A quick read about a Halloween hotspot that turns deadly, you get gruesome deaths, a menacing masked murderer, angsty final girls and a quiet town rocked by tragedy. It’s straight-forward without much depth, but neither are any of our favorite horror films or books centered on the concept of a night of terror. I came for the scares, the screams and the quick pacing and Ihli delivered.

The book gives us multiple perspectives from a victim, a group of girlfriends and the killer. Many of our characters are angsty teens— emotional and horny and up to such antics like brooding over boys, drinking and gossiping. Given the slasher formula, they are doomed. A couple of them have their head on a bit straighter than others—including Norah, who is grieving her brother’s death. It’s fun to predict who may or may not survive. We also get into the head of our killer. I don’t always love when this happens because I think it takes the scare factor down a notch. Once we are in his head it humanizes him and he becomes less scary. I loved the concept of a haunted forest/camp site turned deadly. It’s the perfect setting for a horror story and Ihli does a great job of setting up the scenes with vivid details. You go into this knowing what you’re going to get and I won’t fault it for a lack of depth—it’s a slasher story and while it’s a good one, it definitely lacks layers. It’s exactly as to be expected—the perfect slasher horror formula with new, interesting characters and an epic setting. I’d love to see a book to film adaption. 3.5 stars.

title: I don't get it
text:
A lot of people claim this book to be a classic. 100% disagree. I disliked this book so much - the writing is hard to follow, makes no sense - that once I was done reading I didn't read any of the notes at the end, which I have always done.
Sadly, it's going to be a long time before I decide to read another Faulkner story, that is if I actually decide to try his writing again.

title: Maybe a Little Too Wholesome
text:
After reading "A Brilliant Night of Stars and Ice" (2022) by this author whom I'd never read anything or heard of before now, I was looking forward to enjoying this book, one of her earlier works which was published in 2018. However, this weak plot was all wrapped up by chapter 14 (there are 21 chapters total) and by that point, for this reader, this book was very much over. This is the first in what is supposed to be a fun, lighthearted even whimsical series about a group of single women who get married off, one by one.

It did start off promising.

A large group of mostly forgettable single women, way past their expiration date for the time period in which it is set, 1815, London England who publish articles about their experiences in the local papers. Except for the main heroine of this novel, Georgiana Allen (Georgie) all of her single friends and fellow Spinsters "with a capital S" were hard to root for or follow thanks to all the stereotypes this book couldn't seem to get away from. There's a "shy" spinster, a "play the field having too much fun to commit" spinster, a "plain and homely" spinster...You get it. And it seemed on every single page one of these women was either: scoffing, smirking, hiding a laugh in her sleeve, choking back a laugh, groaning, snorting or huffing as they discussed their single state with each other, the lack of eligible men and usually doing so with the only male character of any importance in this book, Captain Anthony Sterling. Naturally, Tony is your typical romantic novel male who never looked at another woman in his life until he saw our heroine.

One of Tony's friends wants him to break up the Spinsters, they are throwing off the groove of all the carefree bachelors who don't want to settle and commit. These wholesome women must be stopped! If Tony were to get into their inner circle, get the ringleader Georgie to fall in love with him, then all the eligible maidens in Society would again be fair game for the single men to pursue without the cynical, rain-on-our-parade influence of these old maids who, nevertheless, hold a place of general respect in upper-class Society with their opinions and articles. Not a bad story idea by the author but even a 21st century reader knows such women have NEVER held such a place in culture or society. Childless women who have never married achieve their fame by CHOOSING such a life, which was unheard of in 1815 and these women are most certainly NOT single and childless by choice. They just haven't found a husband yet and are the victims of skewed numbers in the dating circles of their day. Even today, such women never make headlines, are treated like second-class citizens and largely ignored and forgotten by everyone. I'm speaking from personal experience here.

This explains why this book by an LDS author was NOT published by Deseret Book or Covenant like "Brilliant Night" was. Not sure exactly why, maybe because of the weak plot and story idea, maybe the fact one character dropped the forbidden "D" word, the only place in the book I noticed while reading-sorry I can't find the reference. Or perhaps when Georgie and Tony realized they couldn't swipe left and hold out for their nine or ten to come along and decided to get together that they couldn't stop sneaking off into corners to steal kisses and passionate embraces. Nothing offensive, don't worry it was all good, clean wholesome fun but, again, just not as well written as "Brilliant Night" which I highly recommend.

Pick this up if you need something to read but I recommend waiting for this author's next book to come out as published and edited by more professional houses than the one this came from.

title: Therapeutic Writing
text: It's not often that I don't finish a book. I fell in love with Cheryl Strayed after reading Wild and Dear Sugar, so I was looking forward to consuming everything I could get my hands on. It's clear, though, that Torch isn't what made her for a reason. There is nothing wrong with the book, it just isn't very compelling. After reading the other books and being familiar with Strayed's story, I can't help but think of this as more of a therapeutic writing project for her to explore her feelings about her mother's death than a story that we are all to share. Maybe if I had never read the other books, maybe if I didn't know it was the same author, maybe then I would like it. But for now, I'm admitting defeat and putting this one down.

title: Dry diplomatic history
text: I eagerly bought this book because it's probably the only one dealing with the Sino-vietnamese war of 1979 as its main theme. Although it contains a very thorough overview of the political and diplomatic relations of the two countries from 1947 to 1979, analysing many issues ranging from the Chinese community in Vietnam to the US-Chinese and Soviet-Vietnamese relations, the actual military operations of the war are covered in only 16 pages of a single chapter (number 5). The writing is also completely dry, reminding official diplomatic report. For someone who's looking for a better military account I would recommend "PLA Warfighting" which is much more detailed on the subject, and also "Brother Enemy" by Nayan Chanda which has an easily read narrative, albeit it focuses on the Vietnam invasion of Cambodia (December 1978 - January 1979).

title: Typical Cotton Malone Book
text:
If you've read one Cotton Malone "thriller", it feels like you've read them all.

Berry does a great job of weaving historical fact with plausible historical fiction, which is the formula he copied from Dan Brown. This is a formula that works well for him, as he's made a great career out of it.

Perhaps I'm just growing tired of this formula, as I did not really enjoy this book. I give Berry credit for moving away from the rather open Misogyny of his earlier books, as he clearly did not know how to include female characters in his story without turning the. Into complete monsters. However, the character development is poor, to the point where I'm struggling to like any of the characters. Cotton comes off as obnoxious while everyone else is a liar/con artist.

The rundown of the history of Mormon mistreatment, along with the reasoning as to why Secession is legal/illegal is interesting, but those historical themes are all this book had going for it. I doubt I'll be picking up another Steve Berry book.

title: Confusing
text: I am an avid reader, usually reading a book in one or two days. I really struggled with this book as I found it very confusing with the multitude of characters and the back and forth with the plot. I will say, it did all make sense at the end, however it seemed to take forever to get there.

title: I knew I'd love this book.  I was wrong
text:
When this book arrived I rushed to my bookcase to pull down my 1922 edition of The Boston Cooking-School Cook Book. It was a slightly newer version than the one this book was based on, but I still expected that it would be fun to read Fannie's Last Supper and compare it with my disintegrating copy of the cook book, imagining what it would be like to put together a dinner party with recipes from 1896. I should have left Fannie on the shelf and taken several other, newer cookbooks instead.

It was a few days before I figured that out, though. I started by reading from the beginning, at the author's story of buying an 1859 Victorian bowfront in Boston. It was, apparently, not a pleasant place to live, with drug dealers on the sidewalk and a working girl with a customer in the neighbor's doorway. The author confronted drug dealers, got ripped off by neighborhood children, and joined a historical society, and his family was robbed at gunpoint and attended a gay wedding, though not at the same time.

All this might make an interesting book, and if I had wanted to read about relocating to South Boston in the 1990s I might have enjoyed it. Eventually I got to the first recipe, Victoria Punch, "courtesy of Donald Friary", who is "an expert on punch and punch bowls and a fellow member of Boston's St. Botolph Club". This was a bit of a surprise since Fannie Farmer had 15 punch recipes, including one for Victoria Punch which has nothing in common with Friary's. But Friary's recipe looks far less sweet and contains ingredients which would probably be easier to find, so perhaps that's the reason for the substitution.

The next chapter introduces Fannie Farmer a bit. "For starters, she was middle-class at best," it begins. Apparently poor Fannie could not have afforded a membership in St. Botolph Club, even if women had been permitted to join in her lifetime. We are, however, assured of Kimball's standing, since later in this chapter he discusses cooking dinner with his good friend Julia Child. One of the two recipes in this chapter, Brown Bread, is based on a Fannie Farmer recipe. The other recipe, Champagne Mignonette (to be served with oysters) has no source that I can find, but doesn't appear in my copy of the Cook Book.

While several other recipes seem to rely on cookbooks published at a point in time near Fannie Farmer's cookbook, such as Escoffier's Le Guide Culinaire, other sources include The Joy of Cooking and Gordon Ramsay. Salmon is grilled, a method not even mentioned in the Cook Book. The one common element throughout the book seems to be a certain level of scorn for Fannie Farmer. "What she may have lacked as a talented cook she made up for with a keen sense of showmanship, marketing, and giving the public what it wanted."

I admit that a big part of my problem with this cookbook is that I could not get past my expectations of "Two Years, Twelve Courses, and Creating One Amazing Meal from Fannie Farmer's 1896 Cookbook". It took me a few days to read most of the book, and two years to convince myself to pick it up again and read the last two chapters. Many parts of the book are quite enjoyable, especially the discussion of handling foods that modern cooks rarely use, like the calf's head. If the book had been marketed as a study of cookbooks from that time period (and if current sources had not been used,) I would have enjoyed it a great deal more.

title: A Big Dud, a Small Book
text: While Rothfuss is a masterful writer of epic prose, with this short tale he falls flat.  I was very anxious to read the story of Auri, a minor but fascinating character in his Kingkiller Chronicles, but unfortunately, it's a lot of nothing.  Deadly dull and boring description, and not much else.  I can't believe he would release something like this, and I hope he gets enough feedback not to try something like this again.  Also, the illustrations are terrible.  Even if you're a diehard fan, I can't imagine you liking this as much as The Name of the Wind or The Wise Man's Fear.  Skip this one.

title: Too little about Chris, too much about other people...
text:
I was hoping that this book would be entirely about Chris McCandless, but a huge portion of it was about the author's own personal life, the lives of McCandless' relatives and friends, and other travelers who the author compares to McCandless. I didn't want to read about other people, I wanted Chris's story. And what we actually get of his story is fascinating and riveting. I just wish we got more of it.

I was also perplexed by how many times we got references to Chris's camera and journal, but the entire book is without photos (save one in the very beginning) and almost nothing from the journal (though we get to read a handful of postcard messages and letters). But upon further research, it seems that Chris's family plans to release another book that will include some photos and other material. Why they weren't included in this book puzzles me. I don't want to believe that the family is using this poor kid's tragic story as a money-making machine, but with multiple magazine articles, a book, a film, and another book on the way... one has to wonder. Chris, after all, wasn't especially close to his family.

I would much rather have had a book filled with photos and journal entries, than Krakauer's confusing, wandering tales that jump back and forth in time (we begin the story with Chris's death? why isn't that at the end?). The timeline of the book is so jumbled that I had trouble keeping track of what was happening, where it was, when it was.

So this book gets 3 stars from me. It was too much like a tease - giving bits of Chris's amazing story, then giving me page after page of other, unnecessary "stuff" before going back to Chris again. Whether he was a reckless idiot or an unfortunate philosopher, his story is touching and tragic.

title: Weir excels at science writing and world-creating, but struggles ...
text: Weir excels at science writing and world-creating, but struggles at character building, dialogue, and plot. His effort to write from a woman’s perspective is especially weak and a serious mistake. The dialogue and narration induce eye rolling at times. Weir should stick with what he knows: physics, space, and problem-solving.

title: OK
text:
Thank you to the author, publisher and Net Galley for providing me with a free Ebook ARC of this book in exchange for my review.

I wanted to like this book. The summary sounded good and I wanted to like this book. But the characters were so wrapped up in self deprecating monologues and complaining, I couldn't connect with any of the characters. I didn't care what happened to any of them and just wanted the book to be over. The world does not need more books full of women complaining about their lives/work/bodies/children/partner's - we're full of that, thanks! Let's have some books with women who are positive about their lives! That don't hate their bodies! That love their families!

Maybe I'm the only one looking for that.

title: Worth reading, but poor writing.
text: To be valued as a unique Japanese-side perspective on the pacific naval camping, but is equally a narcissistic exercise for the author.  He takes every opportunity to buff his reputation down to the silliest of details, and his criticism of Japanese naval strategy and superiors often comes off as petty, all while dismissing Japanese crimes against humanity as "over-exaggerated," referring to the Rape of Nanking.  His own self-criticism is drowned in a sea of fantastic implications, which would have you think he could have chased the American Navy from every corner of the Pacific, had he been given Yamamoto's job.

title: A weak imitation.
text: I am a long standing Agatha Christie reader and fan. This book was okay but I struggled to finish it. It just seemed to try to hard. Read the real Agathas if you miss her writing. Especially if you haven't read them in a while.

title: Engrossing second chance love story
text:
Jane Porter returns to her Rhode Island hometown to help her sister care for their ailing mother. Jane rarely makes the trip due to the painful memories that have scarred her even into adulthood. When she was a sophomore in college, her mother forced her to give up her child for adoption, and it was handled privately, with the baby girl going to a local family.

Dylan Chadwick has also returned home. After his wife and daughter were killed in a crossfire while he was a US Marshall, he has returned to the family apple orchard, determined to bring it back to life. He has forged a loving and protective relationship with his niece, who it turns out, is the child that Jane gave birth to 15 years earlier.

Coming home affords Jane with the opportunity to meet the child she could never forget. Soon, she is spending time with Dylan, who has suddenly come out of his shell, and has fallen for her. She too is smitten with Dylan, but worries that her motivations for being with him will be misconstrued once he finds out about her relationship to Chloe.

Dance with Me is an absorbing story about two lost souls who manage to find each other, only to find themselves at odds. The icy relationship between the sisters and the mother is believable and engrossing.

title: Not an introduction, but good to get a step further
text:
Deleuze’s way of thinking is notoriously hard to understand. I’m not sure I understand it. This book offers some good guidelines, but I wouldn’t recommend it as an introduction.

In the form of various interviews we get a different angle to Deleuze’s philosophy, such as Anti Oedipus and A Thousand Plateaus. We also get a sense of how Deleuze understands the nature and purpose of philosophical activity.

I really liked the interviews about his reading of Foucault. These interviews are insightful to understand concepts from Foucault’s philosophy, such as subjectivation, truth and archaeology of knowledge, as well as the intersection with Deleuze’s philosophy and connections to Nietzsche.

I was very glad to be reading it to a non-reader so that I could skip the boy calling his sister a dummy and the part about the risk of being put to death for treason. We luckily just grabbed this off a shelf at the library and I'll be happy to return it.

title: this is NOT the sequel to THE PHANTOM
text: For those of you as confused as I was, read Mike Cunha's review. He explains that THE REDEEMER is the sixth book in the series, while PHANTOM was the ninth. So I have been waiting months for a book that does not exist yet. A list inside the frontispiece explains that REDEEMER is the sixth book.. As far as the story goes, it is confusing and hard to follow. Nesbo still tries to confuse the reader by describing events but not telling us who is involved. This makes no sense and probably will turn off fans. I am having a hard time enjoying this story...... Well, I finished it. It was the most confusing book I ever read. I cannot recommend it. If I hadn't already read the next 3 books, I would not have finished this one. It is bleak, sad, dark, and very confusing.

title: phoning it in
text: Come on, Dana. You kind of phoned this one in. And ending on that note was just lazy. I feel let down, not because of what you did to the girls, but for writing such a BLAH story, then ending it on something so high pitched. It didn't have the feel of every other Shugak, which rolled through multiple highs and lows and typically ended with at least some resolution.

title: The 'big reveal' was disappointing.
text:
Liane Moriarty is a popular best-selling author and her latest book, Truly Madly Guilty, garnered a lot of hype and many good reviews. That said, the book was just okay for me.

Set in Sydney, Australia, the story is about an unfortunate incident that occurs during a backyard barbeque. The cookout's hosts are Vid and Tiffany - a rich sociable couple that live in a luxurious home with their 10-year-old daughter Dakota. The guests include the hosts' next-door neighbors Erika and Oliver and their friends Clementine and Sam who bring their two little girls Holly (5) and Ruby (2). The story skips back and forth in time, depicting events before the barbeque, on the day of the barbeque, and after the barbeque.

As the story unfolds we learn the backstories of some of the characters. Erika had a difficult shame-filled childhood with her mother Sylvia, a narcissistic and delusional hoarder. Feeling bad for Erika, Clementine's mother Pam took the girl under her wing and pushed Clementine to be friends with her - which Clementine resented. Erika's husband Oliver also had a dysfunctional childhood, with two alcoholic parents. Thus Erika and Oliver - both damaged - understand each other and have a quiet successful marriage.

Clementine, by contrast, had a happy childhood.....aside from being irritated by Erika's constant presence. Clementine had loving parents, a nice home, and musical talent that was nurtured by her family. Clementine is now a professional cellist, happily married to public relations honcho Sam. Though Clementine and Sam's lives are somewhat fraught - with two small kids, two careers, and Clementine's constant fretting about auditions - the couple meanders along quite happily.

Vid is an electrician who resembles 'Tony Soprano' and Tiffany is a successful property developer with an eye-catching sexy figure. Tiffany unashamedly admits she once worked as a pole dancer to make money for school. The couple enjoy throwing parties and Vid loves to cook - so he serves tasty dishes from recipes he finds on the internet. (I got a yen to try some of his dishes....ha ha ha.)

On the day of the barbeque tension arises early because Erika and Oliver make a request of Clementine and Sam that throws the couple off-kilter. So it's not surprising that there's a little too much drinking and hilarity at the cookout, leading to an unfortunate occurrence. A good part of the book drops hints about the incident at the barbeque, details the emotions and actions of the characters, and relates consequences after the cookout. I have to say - after the HUGE build-up - I found the 'barbeque incident' rather predictable and mundane, and the consequences overblown and unrealistic.

That said there are things I like about the story. It has some clever surprises and twists, and some memorable characters and scenes. For example, Sylvia the hoarder (Erika's mom) is sly, phony, funny....and VERY irritating. And social worker Pam (Clementine's mom) is overly self-righteous in her do-gooding, interfering zeal. At one point Pam gives a dinner party speech that made me (and the book's characters) quite uncomfortable. These behaviors - though squirm inducing - add interest to the story. On the other hand, 5-year-old Holly is a hoot when she sprinkles her conversation with "air quotes" on random words.

The first two-thirds of the book held my attention, after which I was slightly bored. And the story's final scenes didn't ring true to me. I would mildly recommend this book to fans of Liane Moriarty but it's not as good as her earlier work (IMO).

title: A History of Modern French Philosophy; Das ist alles.
text: Copleston mixes explanation with critique and the reader often can’t tell which is which. This is the fault of the editor that let his prose, which is rambling and repetitive, be published as is. This is especially true for the chapters on Sartre. It might have been the result of Copleston’s age, for the last chapter is weak, which is unfortunate, since Merleau-Ponty is widely studied today.  Also, the short biography of Albert Camus has errors. Camus was indeed a member of the French Communist Party but was expelled as a result of his sympathy for absurdism and anarchism. He joined several anarchist movements but refused to explain philosophically or rationally the meanings of absurdism or anarchism. He chose the easy way out, writing fiction, which could not be easily criticized, and also offered him a sizable income, to be sure, winning the Noble Prize for literature three years before his death in 1960. Nonetheless, Copleston was well aware of the influence world events had on philosophers and his books are true to this history. Unfortunately, this volume of his History of Philosophy is a misnomer, since it covers only modern French philosophy, which was heavily influenced by Husserl, Heidegger, and other 20th Century German philosophers.

All that said, the story was interesting enough that I wanted to see it through to the end. I did feel vested in the characters and the conclusion is satisfying.

title: Difficult to understand the Many Worlds Interpretation
text:
I bought this book so that I could understand the details of the Many Worlds Interpretation of quantum mechanics. I was disappointed that Peter Byrne does not address how the Many Worlds Interpretation addresses a key quantum mechanics experiment, the Double Slit Experiment. This experiment is particularly challenging for Many Worlds because the possible outcomes are both infinite and not discrete. The wave function could, theoretically, interact with any point on the screen and even points beyond it. And no point is discrete unless and until you reach the Planck length.

Byrne's explanation of Many Worlds begins understandably. But when he gets into the details like the role of probability, I could not understand his explanation. Many of Byrne's sentences are long and complex, which is part of the problem. I gave up and have learned more about Many Worlds from other books.

This book is much more valuable for the biographical information about Everett and the descriptions and quotations regarding the Copenhagen Interpretation than for the explanation of Many Worlds.

title: I Don't Like "I Don't Like Gloria"
text:
I'm not one of these people who thinks every children's book has to be a treacly tome of sunshine and rainbows and unicorns dancing hand in hand with happy endings; far from it, we really enjoy books that take the real emotions kids go through and treat them in a way that lets the kids process them on their own terms.

This is not one of those books. It does not have a redeeming feature or any nuance that makes it good reading for kids, and it's not funny enough to be read by other audiences.

The premise is the dog is jealous of the cat, and the humans are ignoring the dog. OK, fine comic premise. But there's no resolution AT ALL - there's just a rabbit introduced, and now the little girl ignores both the dog and the cat. And then dog and the cat agree they hate the rabbit.

There were places this book could have gone, like the dog and cat learn to play with one another, or they look at the rabbit and realize part of being a family is taking turns getting attention, and so forth, without turning into the aforementioned unicorn-hugfest.

When my five year old read this book -- and we gave it quite a number of spins, with and without adult commentary, because he enjoyed the illustrations -- he processed the negativity but had no appreciation of what might've come next. A book that just focuses on hating somebody else because you're jealous of them is not a good children's book. And it's not funny enough to be read as a joky adult's book or a satire for older children to read, like, say, "Dumb Bunnies" or "Go the @)*$ to Sleep".

Books that provoke kids into purely negative emotions without an appropriately cathartic release are bad books. You might as well take them to an R-rated action movie, where they will at least be entertained by the explosions.

title: Pleasant Diversion for an Afternoon
text:
I enjoyed reading "Don't Lose Her" by Jonathon King, but after I finished, I was left with a sense of dissatisfaction. Private Investigator Max Freeman is called in to investigate the kidnapping of the wife of his best friend, a federal judge who is 8 months pregnant. King head hops from the judge's POV, to Freeman's to the kidnapper's to give the reader a good understanding of what is happening and to allow us to develop sympathy for all who are involved.

King moves the plot along, and it was hard for me to put the book down. I especially enjoyed the setting in the Florida Everglades. Yet, I found the rationale for the kidnapping to be kind of silly, and Freeman largely was a reduced to the role of gofer while his friend Billy, husband of the kidnapped victim, is the one who does the heavy lifting in terms of solving the identify and motive of the people behind the kidnapping-- and he pretty much does it off scene, presenting his conclusions to Freeman as fait accompli.

I don't know that I would read another book in this series, but it was a pleasant enough diversion for an afternoon.

title: Horrible book doctors deeply concerned about.
text: The American Association of Pediatrics ([...]) argues: it "has raised concern among pediatricians because it outlines an infant feeding program that has been associated with failure to thrive (FTT), poor milk supply failure, and involuntary early weaning. A Forsyth Medical Hospital Review Committee, in Winston-Salem N.C., has listed 11 areas in which the program is inadequately supported by conventional medical practice. The Child Abuse Prevention Council of Orange County, Calif., stated its concern after physicians called them with reports of dehydration, slow growth and development, and FTT associated with the program. And on Feb. 8, AAP District IV passed a resolution asking the Academy to investigate "Babywise," determine the extent of its effects on infant health and alert its members, other organizations and parents of its findings."

title: Didn't Clive Read the Galleys?
text: I admit I'm a big Clive Barker, but the first hardcover edition of this book appears to have been rushed to print without anyone reading the galleys, including the author.  And the bottom line is that the buck stops with Mr. Barker, since it is, after all, HIS work.  This book, beyond any doubt, has more copy-editing and typesetting errors than any book I have read in print.  Ever!  At one point, I decided to take notes and filled two pages by the time I was done with the book.  Most of the spelling errors were easy to correct, but took a human to do it -- not an automatic spell-checker.  For example, during one of the orgy sequences, "Roman" is substituted for "Ramon" (when the author obviously intends a reference to Ramon Navarro and not Roman Polanski).  A more serious error involves how the actor Todd Pickett came to hook up with the surgeon who performed botched plastic surgery.  There are two divergent accounts with screwed-up time frames regarding appointments, one that seems to take place before and one after the death of a beloved pet. Obviously, Mr. Barker had done some rewriting here and had forgotten to change what came earlier.  No one else seemed to pick up on this.  The story is enjoyable, with certain similarities to "Weaveworld," but the constant errors are annoying and would deserve a better rating than I have given it if someone (the author? the editor? the copy editor?) had shown enough concern to read through the galleys with a red pencil BEFORE the book was published.

title: Coming of age story set in Paris
text:
The theme for the Mocha Girls Read book of the month in January was Paris. As a group, we voted to read Black Girl in Paris by Shay Youngblood. This relatively short and extremely beautiful book was essentially a coming of age story for its protagonist, Eden, and a lovely way to kick off 2019.

Black Girl in Paris is the story of a young lady and budding writer who picks up from her home in the United States with a little money and travels to Europe in search of the greatness that author James Baldwin wrote about. While there she encounters many people while trying to make a living and find creative inspiration in Paris.

One thing I found it interesting about this book is that Youngblood set it in the 80s while writing it in the millennium. It could have just as easily been set in the time in which it was written. I suspect the author may have done this to demonstrate just how far way from home Eden traveled. With the technology today (and in the early part of the turn of the century), it's so much easier to be close even when there's great physical distance.

Black Girl in Paris reads like a collection of chronological essays. Youngblood's prose is excellent and you want to follow her as a writer and Eden as the main character on this journey of self discovery. This book definitely kept me interested. This is not something I would have read but for book club. And that is one of the greater purposes of book club. I am glad I was able to partake and participate.

My ultimate takeaway from this story is that we cannot escape racism no matter the time nor location.

Recommendation: If you love Paris and the pursuit of one's dreams, this quick read might pique your interest.

Until next time ... Read on!

Regardless of whether I purchase a book, borrow a book, or am gifted one, my ultimate goal is to be honest, fair, and constructive. I hope you've found this review helpful.

What I don't like about the books is where Angel stupidly faces off with local toughs where he is unarmed and nobody knows where he is, and he ends up in the hospital, having accomplished nothing.  This is apparently meant to be the "adventure" side of the book, and I put up with it because it's usually only 10-20% of the book.  I often skim it.  But THIS book is 80-90% of the confrontations with the local (armed) toughs, multiple trips to the hospital and only 10-20% murder resolution. There is no real team effort even then.  Angel just figures it out on his own.  I'm sorry to see the series take this turn.

title: Eve Dallas novella -- a fun enough ghost story
text:
And so this JD Robb novella, “Haunted” {#22.5 in the prolific “In Death” series}, is basically a ghost story. When Homicide Lt. Eve Dallas catches a death at the former NYC nightclub “12”, she discovers, while searching the building, yet another body – just a skeleton actually – complete with a gun laying nearby. Almost unbelievably, the gun {such weapons are now banned in our 2060 Gotham!} was the murder weapon in both deaths, probably separated by five decades or so, leading to the speculation that the skeleton belongs to a famous singer who disappeared a long time ago and now haunts “12”. Various mysterious apparitional appearances and sounds lead to the ghostly rumors, about which Eve and hubby Roarke have a snitty argument. Naturally, Eve works the case and will eventually solve both murders, but it takes her a good while to out the somewhat surprising perp.

160 pages in this edition make for an entertaining hour plus of reading – and probably one’s enjoyment will vary directly with the fun generated by the haunted angle. We might quibble that to us the ending didn’t quite hang together, but nonetheless an amusing enough outing.

title: If you did not want my opinion, you should not have bought my book.
text:
I will establish that I am conservative, but open-minded. I know my biases and have safeguards in place already. I teach classes on critical decision making techniques. I like to hear both sides of a topic, and I like them to be well-argued.

I purchased the book after other reviews convinced me the material had something to offer. I found that it is a one-sided view of the topics. It is hard to read a book that is filled with such a negative view of the way things have become. It offers soft evidence that smells of confirmation bias. In fact, one of the good things about it is to use it as an example of confirmation bias training. So I do not feel too bad that I had purchased this book. I just prefer all the facts be laid out, then the let the author play to his opinions; he should defend his and objectively take apart the opposing views.

His passion in his writing is so strong, I almost feel him standing over my shoulder deriding my views of his comments with "If you did not want my opinion, you should not have bought my book."

While I am sure the author is passionate about his opinions and that has created his negativity, he is entitled to them. He is entitled to publish them and defend them. After all is said and done, that is what the purpose of some of those topics he is so critical of. I think his opinion, the right to express it and the fact that it is published without fear of retribution stand as a monument to the successes of his targets of admonition.

title: Stupid people doing stupid things for money
text:
Nerve was not the exciting action packed book I hoped it would be. I had a LOT of problems with it.

Nerve is about an anonymous online game, which is basically truth or dare, without the truth option. Each person can complete dares to earn prizes and money, and the best ones advance to the grand prize round. High school Junior Vee is typically more of a “behind the scenes” type of person, and never dreamed of ever entering Nerve. When she’s snubbed by the boy she likes, she decides she needs a change, and enters Nerve.

The dares get progressively more “intense” until she’s in the final round with 5 other people who all have to play together in order to win. The further she competes in the game, the more she realizes it’s maybe not a game after all.

I really expected Nerve to be more intense than it was. A lot of the dares felt really easy, but Vee reacted like they were the end of the world, and literally cried at almost every dare. It would be one thing if she was being forced to do things she didn’t want to do, but she voluntarily signed up for the game!?! She also has the option to quit, but she’s too obsessed with the prizes to do that. She’s also obsessed with the boy who gets paired as her partner, so she doesn’t want to stop working with him.

The beginning of the book opened with a prologue that I was really intrigued by, but then the book never really answered what happened with the prologue and never touched on it again – it seemed like it was forgotten, and I found myself wishing more of the book was like the intense prologue!

I found the way some of the characters acted to be unrealistic. Vee’s parents grounded her for something that was important, but the dumbest reason to ground someone. It seemed like a really bad reaction to the event, and made me dislike Vee’s parents.

I also hated how many of Vee’s actions revolved around a boy. She gets in a fight with her best friend over a boy, enters the game because of a boy, chooses not to quit the game because of a boy, and so on and so forth. I wanted to shake her and tell her to form her own identity and NOT make it wrapped up in men! You’re worth more than that!

That said, I hated the epilogue. WHY was it necessary for this book to end on a “cliffhanger”? It could easily have been wrapped up, and it left me rolling my eyes.

Overall, I was disappointed by this one. It was a lot of stupid people making idiotic decisions in order to win money and prizes. I felt like the author WANTED to make it like The Hunger Games, but fell way way short. I can’t say I’d recommend this one.

title: Lied on HGTV
text:
I didn't realize HGTV House Hunters International were such liars, and even encouraged this author to lie. They paint her as a successful novelist, while she has only written this one book. (Also, she is listed in author ranking as over one million).

The show says they will be moving to Australia from Texas. Show aired for first time 5/27/13. She even says to her son, "You think you're going to like it here" as they fish in Australia. Yet her Authors profile says she moved to Australia in 2010 and that is where she wrote her first book. Her family has been living there three years! So why in the world are they pretending that they just moved there, touring phony homes, knowing they already live in the home they selected on the show?

Shame on Tanya, but even bigger shame on HGTV for perpetrating a FRAUD by trying to make us believe she just moved there and getting Tanya and her entire family to lie about it just to get on the show.

I have actually read a bit of this book and it's pretty good. Tanya will probably become a successful author with multiple books. But I don't think I'll read another one after discovering this fraud.

NOTE: If the author profile suddenly changes, removing the details of moving to Australia in 2010, we'll know why.

title: The Same Very Average Book Repackaged  Endlessly
text: Bryan Peterson has got it made. Thirty years ago this book came out and it was just average, nothing notable. Seeing all the incredible ratings, I thought there must have been a major rewriting of this book in the intervening years. I can can confirm that this is the same average book from 1990 with a different cover and the same (but updated) relentless name dropping of the latest Nikon cameras. There’s your difference over 30 years. Peterson shamelessly shills for Nikon with an average book that is the same as it was thirty years ago. Don’t believe me? Go to the copyright page and you will see “Copyright 1990, 2004, 2010, 2016”. This book is being returned pronto. Gosh , it wasn’t a good book even n 1990. Cash cow book.

I did give it two stars because it does a good job of addressing fears and keeping someone from slipping into bad argumentative tactics during an intervention.  I also like the sections that teach you how to provide encouragement when people have decided to make a change in their lives.  Still I have many doubts a drug addict or an alcoholic will sign a "change agreement" even when surrounded.  In an abusive relationship this could be deadly (which is probably why it's not addressed in the book).

title: Okay read.
text:
This book wasn't what I was expecting. I was expecting a cute love story where the popular boy meets the new girl and they fall in love and everything's great. That is not this book at all.

This book was not worth all the hype honestly. It was an okay book, but there were way too many stereotypes for me. The dumb jock, the sexual cheerleader, the nerdy "cool" kids, it was all too much and seemed a little forced.

One thing I really, really enjoyed about this book is the main character, Ezra's growth. He definitely changed throughout the book and it was for the better. As a reader, I got to see him change from a popular jock to someone who wanted to go to college and do something with his life beyond high school. I also really enjoyed Ezra's voice. The male narration was refreshing and I enjoyed it greatly, but that couldn't save the book from getting three stars.

If you like the idea of a manic pixie dream girl, then this book might be for you. It reminded me of Looking For Alaska by John Green, although I never finished that book. A manic pixie dream girl is basically a girl who comes into a boys life and teaches him about adventures and living life. In The Beginning of Everything the manic pixie dream girl is Cassidy Thorpe. I did not like Cassidy. I felt like she wasn't dealing with her problems the right way and not growing like I felt she should. Her mysterious past was a let down when the reader discovers what it is.

All in all, 3 stars. It was okay and there were parts I enjoyed. But I didn't love it.

title: A bit uneven at first, but more coherent in the final section
text:
To me, this seems to be a case where I liked the author’s intentions, but didn’t like how these intentions were carried out in the book. Our protagonist, Laurus, wear many hats and carries several names throughout the book, and perhaps that is a symbolic gesture to his always searching for meaning, identity and redemption.

There is a rambling and a bit incoherent quality to much of the beginning parts to Laurus, and for that reason alone, it was sort of a slog and struggle to try to push onward. This is especially evident in the first two sections. There is a bit of structure in the opening part, where we learn the back story of the protagonist and his uncle, and how he begins his life journey, as well as the tragedy that inspires him to begin his quest. However, in the second part of the book, we are hit with episode after episodes of healing and such, and it just seemed a little too random, aimless and sporadic.

As far as the text itself, I found some of book clunky with wording and expressions and I think it was just a translation issue or something. I also wasn’t a big fan of some of the magical realism that came out of nowhere.

Also, there are several shifts in time that seemingly come out of nowhere and are quite random. One reviewer mentioned how it felt like stories were just thrown in in any order with no relevance or coherence. I agree with that assessment, especially as we proceed into the second part of the book.

That being said, I think the best parts of the book are the final ones, and those made it worth the reading experience. I did enjoy several parts, such as the latter sections of Arseny’s pilgrimage to Jerusalem and the spiritual and physical quest he undertakes to get there. Much of this journey is a sense of coming to terms with his guilt over a particular tragedy, and seeking redemption. So, to me, this section not only flowed with much more structure and precision, but the themes were more prevalent as well.

I heard many comparisons to the likes of Umberto Eco and Fyodor Dostoevsky. However, I think those comparisons were a little too ambitious. Not a bad read, but just a tad too uneven and clunky.

title: A unique kind of awful
text:
A unique kind of awful. This might very well be the worst book I have ever read. The strange thing is, usually when I dislike a book, I stop reading and choose something else. This book, however, was so unbelievably awful that I couldn't make myself stop. I had to see how much worse is got and I was really really rooting for every single character to die a horrible death.
The two women characters are both dumber than a bag of rocks and the main male character is so terrible that there is no way either of these women would want him, let alone both. I was hoping he would end up murdering them both, then some random character like Jason Voorhees showing up at the 11th hour and killing him. That's how bad the book is, I daydreamed about the characters being murdered.
Add in some sex talk with words like c*** and Daddy, and you've got a nice, flaming crap cocktail. I even wanted the stupid house to explode!
I'm curious to find out who the author really is, because it has to be someone with their foot already in the door. There is no way this book impressed someone so much as to offer this person a contract. Someone's daughter or lover who was blackmailing people... Something! I refuse to believe this crap got published based on its merits alone.
And what the hell is Ron Howard doing with this? His movies have been some real stinkers lately, but this is bottom of the barrel. This will make the Grinch look Oscar worthy.
AVOID AT ALL COST!!!

title: Middle grade fiction just misses the mark
text: I wanted to like this book more than I did, and I recognize that it is loved by many. I found that I was again and again put off by Ruthie's references to the "dumb class" throughout this novel. As an adult reader, I drew some conclusions. I assumed that ESL children were sometimes placed in remedial classes without regards to other options or additional supports. I also assumed that the author may have had a real-life experience as a child with this worry because Ruthie would not let it go. Ever. The notes at the back of the book confirmed this. I admit that I sped through the last half of the book waiting for Ruthie to articulate her frustration with misplacement of ESL children while also showing some humanity for all of the children who were assigned to the remedial class. If that happened aside from her thanks in receiving a get-well card from the class, I did not see it. This ongoing fear of being a student in this class and commentary from Ruthie made it difficult for me to care for her in the way a reader usually cares for a child protagonist of a book. I feel like this is a book that would cause more damage than good in a read-aloud. I loved the connection to Nancy Drew, Cuba, Poland, refugees, Jose Marti, Frida Kahlo and the infusion of so many cultures within her world. I liked that the central problem of healing, isolated from her usual world and activities, is not one often seen in middle grade novels. It's something that does become a reality for kids dealing with injuries and illnesses, and they should be able to see this represented in the pages of a book. By the end of the book, I found myself more interested in the untold stories of the children in the class that Ruthie scorned. I understand that this may be an unpopular opinion, and this book will do fine without my praise. If I could send Ruthie a book to read while she healed, it would be Hunt's Fish in a Tree.

title: Ok  But ......
text:
First let me say I really like this author she has a great writing style. This book I feel is not her best work.

The storyline centers on a group of people who are hiding from the Nazis in a forest with the help of a girl who spent her life growing up in the same forest after being kidnapped.

If you're looking for a WWII Resistance story this is not the book for you. If you're looking for a book that borders on a fantasy story with a little WWII worked into it then this is the book for you.

Without giving too much away in case you want to read it I will say I was disappointed in the book. It was way to easy to predict the ending which is unusual for Harmel. Some parts just didn't seem to fit some parts were slow with too many descriptive phrases.

If you're looking for a good book from this author I recommend The Room on Ru Amelie also, 2 other books about the Resistance which are great are Dragonfly by Leila Meacham or A Fire Sparkling by MacLean.
