title: Fascinating wilderness world, but ultimately this story frustrated me
text:
This might be the first time where I picked up a book that a few of my SF&F blogger friends enjoyed... and didn't like it as much as they did. Which is a bummer, because Sarah Beth Durst does a few things quite well in THE QUEEN OF BLOOD. I just wish its weaknesses hadn't frustrated me so much.

THE QUEEN OF BLOOD is the first book in a YA/adult crossover epic fantasy series that features malevolent nature spirits, human youths (mostly girls, but also the occasional boy) who can control these spirits, and queens who are skilled in this practice and chosen by the spirits to keep the tenuous peace between nature and humanity. Daleina is one such candidate for this honor. At age 10, her village is destroyed in a spirit attack, and her powers manifest for the first time as she saves her family. The horrors she endured spur her to join one of Aratay's academies later on so she can protect her people. But as Daleina grows older and learns to harness her powers, spirit attacks like the one her village suffered continue to plague Aratay. Who's behind these attacks? Is Queen Fara losing her sway over the nature spirits? Most frightening of all, what if the attacks aren't accidents at all?

For me, the two dominant strengths of THE QUEEN OF BLOOD are worldbuilding and plot. The best word to describe the forest realm of Aratay is "wilderness." It's inhabited yet untamed, dangerous and beautiful. Its people are closely tied to the land and the spirits they co-exist with. Entire villages and cities are constructed in gigantic trees. The lore of the nature spirits and the overall way of the world is demonstrated quite well without info-dumping, so it's easy to become immersed in Aratay's happenings.

As for the plot, it seems fairly straightforward until the second half - and then HOLY PLOT TWISTS. This story serves turn after turn as it closes in on the end, and the suspense mounts to the point where you absolutely NEED to know how it ends. I did predict one of the plot twists correctly (it's easy to guess who's behind the spirit attacks), but the others... Wow. I did not see them coming, and they make for a fitting yet unexpectedly brutal ending.

The characters of THE QUEEN OF BLOOD, though... I did like Daleina a lot. She's far from any "chosen one" or "special snowflake" trope. Rather, she's one of the weaker students in her academy magic-wise, but she compensates for it with courage, determination, and an enviable work ethic. Her motivations are noble, too; she's more concerned about her family and the welfare of Aratay's people than power or prestige. But the other characters... Apart from Ven, I don't feel like I got to know them very well. The other academy students seemed too similar and blended into one another by the end, and Queen Fara was a stereotypical corrupted queen-seductress-madwoman.

I also wasn't that impressed by the writing in THE QUEEN OF BLOOD. Durst certainly knows how to build a believable world and plot an exciting story. But for a fantasy novel that's meant to appeal to both YA and adult audiences, the writing lacked a distinct voice and sense of maturity. And for me, the quality of an author's writing can either enhance the story and fold me further into its spell, or disengage me from the experience. I think you can guess where this book fell on that spectrum.

Ultimately, THE QUEEN OF BLOOD frustrated me as much as it fascinated me. And that's a shame, considering the stunning and unique worldbuilding. Maybe if the sequel improves on this first book, I'll continue the series.

Maybe...

title: An inspiring concept, but lacking in execution...
text:
I liked this book.

The antagonists were really vile, which was great...it makes rooting against them that much more fun. The problem? The protagonists weren't much better. Darren Street isn't a particularly likable character.

I had a real problem with Mr. Street's behavior following his meeting with Jalen Jordan. A professional gentleman, who has even an iota of sense, would be figuring out how best to protect his son...not going to person after person telling them he's going to "kill Jalen."

Mr. Street said dingbat words and did dingbat things, and then was surprised when he ended up in jail? I mean, I'm a parent. I get the fear. But a man who spends every day of his life working in the criminal justice system should know better.

Otherwise, I really enjoyed the perspective of the story. It's not often you read a story about an attorney in a maximum security prison. That part of the story was super interesting, and I honestly wish Mr. Pratt had delved in a bit more deeply.

The final 20% of the book....meh. A little implausible, but satisfying, nonetheless. Not sure whether or not I'll continue with the series or not at this point.

title: Husbands and Trees
text:
Aunt Bitzy writes to her niece begging for help to save Emily. Emily is a tree house the new neighbor is going to chop down.

That's true enough, but Bitzy leaves out her plans to create a real life romance. Her main characters being Susannah and neighbor Jake. It's a cute and fun read. I wish it had been longer so the characters had more development. Bitzy is a hoot. The lovers aren't nearly as fun.

It's good, but it could have been better. I was irritated when I started the book because the last Kasey book I read before had a Suzanna as the main character too. It was a bit confusing!

title: Preaching to the Choir
text:
I tried to be open and listen to this. I reached a point, I just couldn't go any further. Maybe it was the style. Maybe it was the vitriolic writing rather than impartiality? Or perhaps it was the opinions stated as fact? Maybe it is the glorification of the past without regard for what it has caused in the future? For example: While it is true that social security initially started as a social redistribution program paid for by the rich, it isn't a glorious program when it became compulsory to be paid for by everyone. Dare I mention that it has now grown to be one of the largest unfunded mandates in the U.S.? And Medicare? Has it really pulled the common people out of poverty? Between Social Security and Medicare they are the top two problems with the national debt. So while they might have been good ideas at the time, over time they act as the biggest debt chains on everyone in the U.S.

Or another example - the term 'Economic Equality' when used by a liberal. Economic equality to a liberal means that those who work or have money support the lazy ones . Why don't they just say socialism or communism and bring up Russia or China? Russia collapsed and China found that people wouldn't work if they couldn't be rewarded for their efforts.

So while it may be true that conservatives Bush and Reagan did bad things, it is also true that the liberals have done some abominable things to take away the rights and economies of the common person.

So while this may be a study in viewpoints that perhaps shows a different perspective to conservativism, this book isn't what I had hoped it would be. The Conscience of a Liberal appears to be one that only states a half truth rather than a balanced viewpoint.

title: Nice series
text: Love the Jack Reacher series so I thought this would be a good series to read. It was good but it is about the two FBI agents who have been assigned to do a background investigation on Reacher.

title: annoying voice
text: I hate to criticize such a good author but she really should have paid someone else to read her books aloud.  Her voice sounded nasally throughout and, as pointed out in another review, the voice she uses for Annie is whiny and grating.  Thank goodness my 8 year-old did not complain of these issues but I do plan to put all the books on his MP3-player so he can listen with headphones and not irritate everyone else in the car.

title: It has a dollar store quality to it

But, it's printed on both sides of the page so if you're like me and want to save for different things at the same time, you can't just cut out a page and tape it to the container. It's not worth the price (for me at least). It seems like something I would find at the dollar store. It's nothing extraordinary that's for sure.

title: 9, 6, & 4 year old each missed the point
text:
We read this to our kids and none of them got it. The pictures are pretty, and the concept is neat for an adult who can understand what the author means. But, the sentences are short fragments, and every page required an exhaustive explanation. There is no storyline. Our kids ages 9, 6, and 4, were all confused. If you’re looking to teach empathy, I really liked the children’s book called, “Those Shoes.”

I have no doubt the author had great intentions, and if you’re planning to use this as a discussion guide with older children, I see it being good for that purpose. My intention was to read my kids a bedtime story about empathy, and this was not good for that.

title: John Wilkes Booth

title: The most boring book that I have ever read

title: Story line was okay, but I wasn't prepared for ...
text: Story line was okay, but I wasn't prepared for so much expletive language.  I don't believe that any other Patterson authored or co-authored book has had as much vulgarity as this one.  It really didn't need as much as it had.  Other than the language, the book was okay.  It took until the last 4-5 chapters to really feel involved with the story line, though.  Not as compelling reading as other novels Patterson has written.

title: Overrated. Unhelpful. Mind blowing that this book could get anything above 3 stars
text: Overrated. Unrelatable. Humble brag. Funny stories that don’t make a point. Self centered. The only help for reader are 3 bullet points at the end of the chapter. It’s kind of like she’s writing these funny humble brag chapters and is like “oh crap I’m supposed to offer some self-help advice” so she throws in the bullet points .  All of the “advice” is soooooo common sense.

title: Inspires travelling + 25 percent of the photos are too small & have no caption + 4 photos not enough to decribe each city.
text:
THE GOOD

- This book is good in the way that it inspires us to travel.

- Each city is covered in 2 pages. The pages are large. They measure 12.5" x 10". So, the text information is adequate.

- There are at least 4 photos for each city. A few such as Tokyo has 8. In total, this book has more than 400 photos.

- The photo are sharp and colorful.

- It lists places of interest and famous citizens of each city.

THE BAD

- I believe 4 photos can not adequately describe the beauty of a city. Eight photos will do. That means the book would be 480 pages thick not 240 as it is now. That was manageable but may be the publisher did not like the extra cost.

- About 25 percent of the photos are smaller than 1/8th the size of the page. That makes it too difficult to clearly see the details. For example, on page 11 about Algiers, the fourth picture at the bottom is very small.

- At least 25 percent of the photos has no caption! This really annoys me. For example, on page 11 about Algiers, the fourth picture at the bottom has no caption. Therefore, I can't tell what city or street these people are kneeling in. Every two pages have this problem.

- I can easily get more information photos of these cities from the web. However, it won't yield photos as beautiful as these.

In short, it's worth viewing in the library.

title: Sloppy Hack Work
text:
How is this book getting such high marks? Family and friends of the author? It's sloppily researched, unevenly edited and reads more like propaganda than history.

And if that's not bad enough, much of Kershaw's writing is cringe inducing:

Panzer tanks? Why not automobile cars?

And why the constant quotation marks to call out terms everyone knows the meaning of: "piece of cake," "jolly good sport," "grim reaper" ...

And do we really need to know the telephone at the airfield was made out of Bakelite every time it rings? That the Spitfire's engines were made by Rolls-Royce? The Messerschmidt's by Daimler-Benz? That the Spitfire's canopy screen was made out of a type of plastic called Perspex? It's all so much word padding and it gets annoying fast.

When it comes to the Germans Kershaw is so out of his depth he should of just stuck with the RAF pilots.

Hans Guderian? Really. An author writing about World War II doesn't catch something that obvious?

title: An easy read
text:
I did not know anything about Hayley Mills although we are contemporaries. The movies she made for Disney were not my cup of tea. However, I enjoyed her description of family and school life, although it was problematic at best. She writes fairly well, but I wouldn't call it "literature".

What totally surprised me is that she is a product of the 60's but only by dint of birth. Her life was so controlled, I found it stifling. She remembers her parents as close and nurturing but I don't see how being raised by a nanny on a separate floor of the house is truly "close and nurturing". They were totally involved with themselves, first and foremost. She went back and forth to Hollywood making movies for Disney but was almost a cipher in her personal life. Very sad, actually, because when she is finally 21 she becomes involved with a much older man who is also very controlling and has an unenviable past. What a waste!

So, I only recommend this book as a peek into a domestic situation that I doubt exists anymore. And, the drinking.................I think most were alcoholics.

title: Fictionalized early New England history lesson
text:
Mother-less Bethia is allowed to wander Great Harbor to her heart's content in this novel set in the mid-1600's on the pretext of gathering wild foods. Along the way she meets a Wampanoag youth she names Caleb and they traverse the dunes, forests, streams and shore of present-day Martha's Vineyard together. Along with teaching her how to forage better, they teach each other their native languages and Bethia introduces him to her version of Christianity.

Due to circumstances beyond her control, Bethia ends up an indentured servant when her father dies, following her brother and Caleb to Boston and Harvard, to help finance her brother's scholarship. While she has surreptitiously absorbed her father's drilling in Latin, the Bible and the letters while at the family hearth faster than her brother, she is expected to hide her learning and toil to advance her brother's status. Meanwhile she gets to keep an eye on her friend Caleb and act as a mother to the younger students being tutored at the house she is indentured to.

While this is an excellent lesson about early New England history and mores, it failed to grab me in the manner of Ms. Brook's earlier People of the Book. Perhaps it was the total sweep of history and cultures that was revealed bit by bit in that previous book that made me love it, everything from contemporary times to Jewish persecution in Spain during the Inquisition to Arab scholars in World War II. This is a nice read but I heartily recommend the earlier work if you have not devoured it already.

title: Mixed bag of sci-fi irony
text:
I don't think I've come across unicorns and other fairy tale creatures in space before, so "Space Unicorn Blues" was definitely unique. It was also light in tone, humorous and pretty wild when it came to space adventures. I found it to be philosophical and slightly absurdist approach to discussing serious "world issues" in a "oh well, that's what it is" manner.
What didn't quite work for me were the characters. I was having a hard time liking anyone. I didn't like Jenny very much mostly because while she has done terrible things in the past, we meet her at a point where she's past those and trying to be nice. There isn't anything terrible about her now and she's sincerely apologetic, but since the horrible stuff she's done is constantly mentioned, I had a weird discourse in my general feelings about her. I guess I wanted to see the struggle, maybe? It's like you'd meet an ex-Nazi character who worked in concentration camps a few years back, but now he's all good, doing the right stuff, saying the right things... And that’s your protagonist. (It was very much Jenny’s story, more so than Gary’s).
I didn't particularly like Gary either. Reason - Gary didn't have much of a personality. He was as flat, emotionless and languid as they come. Now one could argue if that's because Gary is part-unicorn and maybe they aren't very emotional beings, so we have this effect, or maybe it's just Gary himself, yet we get this part good guy part doormat combination that wasn't very appealing. Ricky is morally ambiguous and very questionable, helping you one moment and selling your momma out next…Honestly, no one got much affection from me when it came to characters, besides dwarfs maybe. I'm usually having a hard time with books like that.
This issue aside, it was well-written and had some good thoughts on different social, racial and political problems presented as a sci-fi wild romp, without being preachy. I’m not quite sure whether I’d like to continue with the series, just hanging at 50/50 for now. I’d recommend checking this out of the library before making commitment of buying – you might really like it or might pass, there is no telling until you try.
Happy Reading!

title: Good idea, poorly executed
text: Riddled with errors. These are some that we have caught so far this semester (I am sure there will be more before the end of the semester): p. 2 says "the three-column account form is used," yet they use four-column format. The book is missing the half of the tax table that is needed for the two highest paid employees. The instructions say to number the bills as they come in, yet we can't see why, since the bills already have invoice numbers. Accts Payable and Accts Receivable ledgers are in almost-but-not-quite alphabetical order. Two out of five students had to return their books because of printer error: The books were missing pages, with other pages repeated.

This is a typical partisan political book: the author makes some worthwhile criticisms; but there are also several weaknesses: Lies only covers lies from side of the political spectrum, no index or bibliography, these subjects have been covered before more extensively (for example Orsekes and Conway go into much more detail on the climate science deception).

title: Blah
text:
The original novel with Nick Woods brought us a paranoid loner, with a passion to revenge the death of his wife. This book is as far from that as you can get. His one revenge sniper act is treated as an aside. No big deal. Then off we go on a romp to Nigeria with Nick Woods' military contractor entourage. He is now a bureaucrat beset with other bureaucrats. He must fight all of three battles in this book, the rest is administrivia. It is an average story with a "read-somewhere-else" plot. Not much suspense, no twists, no paranoia, just hum-drum writing.

I suggest the author get back to the original premise of Nick Woods and leave out his struggles with Corporate America.

title: Winning-Over a Pony
text:
Young students can be very observant. A few of my young read-to students pointed out the illustrator's inconsistency in the story. On pages 1-2, Anna is walking to find her pony, Prince. She is wearing blue overalls with a bib and straps that cover her shoulders. By the time she gets to the small herd on pages 3-4, she is now wearing brown pants and somehow there's a sweater involved according to the text. Prince has a blue streak flashing out of his open mouth, which is supposed to be his tugging on a sweater, although his mouth is open and the "sweater" seems to be coming from UNDER Anna's short-sleeve shirt--and an open mouth equals no tugging. The rest of the story has no illustrator-author incongruities.

We do learn from the story how a horse has to develop trust in a handler, a handler needs patience with a horse, and how some horses are easily spooked by unfamiliar sights and sounds. It is a warm story about a young girl (including her grandmother) who has set her sites on a particular yet-to-be-ridden young pony, and a human-pony friendship that is beginning to develop.

I did not find the unfolding of the story dramatic or heart-tugging. Some books get a round of applause from the younger set, but this is not one of them. There are three books in this Anna-Prince series.

Picture book: realistic fiction, K-2

title: Just Grace
text: Just Grace is a lot like the book, Fortunately, Unfortunately, made into a chapter book.  Created to appeal to the beginning readers, much of the vocabulary is above that level.  Lots of cartoons, drawings, diagrams, charts, and the hand shaded short chapter titles, break up the text. Some of the worry-wart problems seem true-to-life, (like the substitute teacher and the mapping lessons.)  Others seem somewhat contrived, (Augustine Dupre coloring her hair.) The flow seemed choppy-- jumping from one idea to another, then an observation "Grown-up brains are like old sponges--they are worn out and can't pick up stuff very well, plus they are already pretty full.  Sometimes too full to hold anything new--like when Mom forgot my fifty cents for bake sale day, even though I probably reminded her about it three, four, or even five times." The book Just Grace creates for the "new sister" [ who actually turns out to be a brother] is done with stick figure drawings like a preschooler would do.  Just Grace is a third grader in the story.  Most eight-year-olds would have a well developed story with quality drawings, so that was disappointing.  I will try the book in my classroom this fall and see how the students respond.

title: ... this book to read this week - and I love cookbooks! I have quite a few of them
text:
I got this book to read this week - and I love cookbooks! I have quite a few of them, and always prefer books with clear photos of the dishes described. It helps me when I am choosing a recipe to prepare. If I can't see the picture, and I am not familiar with the dish, I have to carefully read the recipe, and try to imagine, which I don't always have time to do. Also, when we are talking cookbooks, we judge them by the pictures. We cannot smell the food, we cannot taste it yet, so we have to use our vision sense to help us imagine, and smell the dish if you will. If something is not photographed right, you can usually still have a feel of what it would be, but if there is no picture at all - it is just hard to imagine what the book is telling you to do. No pictures next to recipes is a major downfall of this book.

Now, there are some pictures as dividers of chapters but they are not named, and it is hard to see what recipe they actually represent. This book looks more like an old-fashioned cookbook without those key pictures. Even bloggers like myself with no budget, and passable photography skills can take pictures to show. I understand the author has no budget for photography but should have made a better effort - I could take pictures for free just to be mentioned in the book! I am sure a lot of other starting out photographers would do it - and it is not hard, you are going to cook those dishes anyways, why not take pictures?

Here is what I like about the book - it gives a recipe of homemade garam masala, even several versions of it. This mix is essential for Indian cooking, and it helps to see this book's version as it is such a great spice to have - I use it a lot, I buy mine pre-mixed, but when I get to a point of having more time for cooking I will definitely consult this book for advice!

One recipe that I also find to be more of a filler is the recipe of plain basmati rice. This is a specialized cookbook. I can find how to cook rice on the package of rice, or look it up. I don't really need to be taught how to make rice in a specialized book - this is an easy recipe, and too basic to list in my opinion, or it shouldn't take the whole page, but be a part of a recipe that uses rice like pilaf. I don't know, that's my opinion.

Other than these comments, I think the recipes in the book are very regional, sound delicious, and it is great to be able to learn and share the knowledge of the chef by trying these out - sounds like a lot of family and regional secrets revealed in this book, so my trips to my favorite Indian restaurants are going to be less now since I can simply cook all of those dishes myself - and I trust they will turn out! A lot of new to me dishes that I will love to try like carrot halva, spiced fried eggplant, and makhanwala - an intriguing name!
I received this product at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

title: Anglo-centric viewpoint based on selected Wiki articles and lots of pics
text:
Unlike the other reviewers here, i was underwhelmed. The ambling preamble promised NEW insights into the 'flak war', but none were forthcoming.

MINUS ONE STAR: Failure to analyze or even mention some of the most decisive AA battles of the war, such as the successful Allied air defense of the Remagen Bridgehead or the pivotal role played by Admiral Lee's battle line during the Battle of the Philippine Sea.

MINUS ONE STAR: Questionable data. Too many times this author cites 'facts' that are in complete disagreement with those cited by reputable sources. Example 1: the effectiveness of the US Navy's 5/38 vs 20mm and 40mm mounts. The author cites an extremely low effective rate (based on pre VT-fused data sets?) that i cannot find corroborated by any other source. The Author's number is in fact 37% lower than any other source's mid 44 -- 1945 data. This book, more than any other, should at the very least explain the difference. Example 2: The author claims the first use of fully automated gun laying (US 90mm AA guns coupled with the M9 gun director coupled with the SR584) occurred during the defense of Antwerp (Nov 44). Other sources cite Henderson Field (1943) or Anzio (early 44). Why the discrepency?

MINUS ONE STAR: Unsubstantiated Claims. One example: Author claims war time experience shows that low to mid level air attack against an alerted AA defense was doomed to fail. Really? Perhaps he should imagine himself in the shoes of a Japanese AA gunner in 1943 New Guinea attempting to defend his airfield against a treetop B25 strafing/parafrag attack.

title: ... help gently lull little ones to sleep and develop good sleeping habits was not at all what I expected
text:
This children's book written to help gently lull little ones to sleep and develop good sleeping habits was not at all what I expected. It is written by a child psychiatrist and rather than be a sweet calming book it uses psychological visualization, and is supposed to have a hypnotic affect on the reader and listener. There is even a warning in the front of the book not to use it in a car while driving.

That's not for me. I personally am disappointed in Zondervan for publishing such a book and it will have no place in my house.

The book itself had a cute story about a little bear and his friends having a big day at the beach and what they do when they return home and prepare for bed. The illustrations are colorful and fun, but hypnosis? No thanks!

***This book was provided to by by booklookbloggers.com in exchange for my honest review.

title: Mediocre is a charitable description
text:
I wouldn't call myself a Hillerman fan, but I have read a few of his other novels and enjoyed them. This one, however, was almost torture.

The story is ludicrous. A Vietnam-era rogue CIA agent who supposedly stole millions commits robberies with multiple-murders for a few thousand dollars. Then the, supposedly super-secretive, big-time secret agent allegedly worth millions moves from his San Francisco home to the same part of the desert where he committed some of these penny-ante robberies and allows pictures of the interior of his new house to be published in an architectural magazine - pictures that show some of the stolen loot.

Nonsensical. Ludicrous. Just plain silly. And it gets worse.

Retired Navajho police detective Joe Leaphorn follows up on a thin lead from his old buddy, another retired cop who has nothing to do who simply disappears after paying a visit to - guess who? - Mr. Super-Secret Former CIA agent living a well-publicized life in the desert.

The former CIA guy just happens to employ, as a virtual slave laborer, a Hmong whom he "rescued" from Laos when he was a child. Tommy Vang alternates between playing one of the dumbest characters to grace the pages of a bad novel to one of the most astute. The character makes no sense and seems more like a device to keep Hillerman from actually having to face the difficulty of plotting.

There are inconsistencies galore in this book. And surprising gaffes, like Hillerman checking the "safety" on his revolver. Revolvers don't have safeties. The ending is pretty silly as well. Hillerman refers to people using e-mail in era when e-mail was not available to the general public. The same with Indian gambling casinos.

In all, a pretty pathetic piece of work. Not throw-away bad, but not terribly satisfying in any way.

Jerry

title: Cute (in a good way) and simple, great for little kids. Not so much for me.
text:
Review by Squeaky Books guest reviewer: River

The biggest problem I had with this book is a personal one: it was written young. I was hoping for a young adult novel, which I usually think of as anything suited for kids 12 or 13 and above. However, this book sat at about more of a fifth grade level, complete with cute (and I do mean cute in a nice sense, not a derogatory one) little pictures every couple dozen pages. It didn't help the age level when the main character and her sidekicks were also in elementary school. I haven't read a book from the perspective of an innocent little kid in a long time and it was a hard adjustment.

It had an atypical feel for a fairytale retelling, in that it seemed so innocent and young and naive. Even though the basis for this story is a little darker, the book seemed relatively happy and simple. It just simply wasn't suited for the age group it's sold to. I gave it to my little sister who was twelve at the time and told her to read it and tell me what she thought. She read it, shrugged and said it was a simple, easy read. She didn't dislike the book, but she wasn't crazy about it either.

A simple, innocent read for younger children in elementary school is basically what this book is. It's not a bad book and there's nothing inherently wrong with the storytelling or characters, it's just young.

title: The Lesser(?) of Two Evils
text:
The time is in the distant future. There are several human empires in the galaxy. Two of them are at odds with each other and neither is a particularly thrilling choice.

On the one hand, the "Risen Empire" is ruled by an emperor who has been dead for centuries. He was once a doctor who tried desperately to save his kid sister from a fatal disease. He succeeds, sort of. He finds a way to introduce a "parasite" that keeps the body animated and the mind active after death. He tries it on himself in a grand suicide and then bestows this gift on his sister. The result is immortality after a fashion. Another result is raw power. By being able to bestow immortality on selected people, he is acclaimed as emperor. The living now have to maintain the overhead of an increasingly large population of the dead.

Another empire which sprang from humanity is very different. It is one of artificial intelligences of planetary scope. These intelligences exist only to propagate themselves throughout the galaxy. A faction of humanity worships these intelligences and has in turn been modified by them.

As the book opens, the cyborgs have attacked an imperial planet in an effort to seed a mind. In doing so, they have captured the sister of the emperor and the imperial fleet is in place to try and stop this propagation. They do manage to defeat the hostage takers but not before the mind is seeded or the imperial sister is killed. The emergent mind learns a secret about the emperor before its commandos are killed. We never learn what that secret is but the mind will do anything to get its one remaining commando into a position to transmit the information to one of its ships still in place. The emperor is so frightened by this possibility that he will sacrifice anyone and anything to prevent it.

Caught in the middle are two principle persons. One is the captain of the ship tasked to attack the cyborg ship and the other is his lover, a powerful senator of the opposition.

The book is well written and keeps interest throughout. It posits some interesting ideas and has a good story. The fact that we don't know what the secret is makes for a minor irritation but the only real problem is the ending. The stage is set for a confrontation between the captain's little ship and the alien behemoth. The stage is set but the actors never get where they are going. We will have to wait for the next book to learn anything.

title: Read and feel special
text:
"The League of Unexceptional Children" is this little fluffy entertainment that won't blow your mind, but will give you much needed laughs and giggles.
As two very average kids being recruited as spies (because they are so ordinary that no one notices or remembers them) to save USA from falling to pieces, we get to follow them on this fast fun ride of a story. While main plot won't rock your socks off with originality and complexity, I believe that this book actually never meant to do it in the first place. It doesn't have any pretenses on being something important or significant; the strength of "TLOUC" lies in the humor of it, which is extremely self-deprecating, yet innocent at the same time. I really liked "introductions" from kids (and an adult) to each chapter, and yes, my dog also sometimes looks at me in a "Come on, even I could have done that better!" way. Apparently I can relate.

I also believe that since kids are portrayed in SUCH an outrageous, over-the-top manner of "average-ness" that even the shiest,most self-doubting kid reading this book will find something special in him/her and feel good about it. As a matter of fact, anyone can feel good about themselves nest to Shelley, Jonathan and ESPECIALLY Arthur. Therefore, let's take advantage of this gift in the hard-knock life we're living and feel our intelligence rise with every word coming out of Arthur's mouth. Good times!

"The League of Unexceptional Children" is a good one-time fluff that will lift your mood and make you smile; sometimes it's all one need to feel better and get over a certain slump. Try it for yourself - all kinds of giggles, chuckles, laughs and possible snorts are practically unavoidable while reading this book!

title: which makes the bread machine awesome! The recipes are nice
text:
This book is mistitled. Most of the recipes, maybe 98%, you're only using the bread machine as a mixer. You could use any old stand mixer with the dough attachment. This is NOT a bread machine recipe book.

The whole point of a bread machine is that it saves energy. Firing up the oven costs money. And when you live in the desert, where summers hit 115, the last thing you want to do is run the oven for an hour in the summer. But you still want fresh bread, which makes the bread machine awesome!

The recipes are nice, so I couldn't give it one star, but the three or four bread recipes in this book that actually use the bread machine are very basic and I have similar versions in three other cook books - that are ACTUALLY bread machine cook books.

title: Disappointing for Meltzer
text: Parts of this novel flow like most of Meltzer's novels but other parts are so unlikely to happen that suspending disbelief just did not work. The format of alternating time periods is not one I like and honestly I am tired of it, I prefer a linear story development. The main fault of the novel lies in the characters abilities. Everything goes right when either one is in danger and they have abilities far beyond their expected toolboxes. This is a disappointing Meltzer read that I will not be recommending.

title: Research version, not reading-for-pleasure version.
text:
I think which version of this you want depends on why you are reading it.

If you are a scholar, this might be your version. I assume it's close to the original. But the original is fragmented, and unclear, so if you just want to appreciate the story, this is NOT the edition you want.

Here's the opening paragraph:

"He who saw the deep, the country's foundation
[who] knew ... , was wise in all matters."

If you want to just read it, [who] and missing words "..." are just an annoyance. And it goes on like this.

If you are researching, the faithful representation may be a plus, if you just wanted to get familiar with the story, as I did, you'll want a different edition.

title: Biased
text:
Well written but biased. The author makes it very plain that he does not like Frederick and I felt like I was reading a book about Hitler written by a Frenchman.

After describing a battle in which Frederick displayed brilliant leadership and bravery beyond anything I have ever read about before; the author takes time to tell of the personal habits of Frederick that are disgusting to the author.

This same process of a little history and a lot of petty criticism goes on for the entire book.

The author is British and Frederick was Prussian.

I don't have a recommendation for another book on Frederick, but it is worth the effort to find a more balanced one.

title: Cotton Candy
text:
Al Strachan’s book is a nice biography of Wayne Gretzky’s achievements in hockey. He touches briefly on all aspects of Gretzky’s career and gives you just enough insight to wet your appetite before moving on to his next topic. Unfortunately, the book as a whole was like eating cotton candy: sweet and tasty but not filling.

Strachan, who is a hockey journalist and a good friend of Gretzky, certainly provided some glimpses under the curtain (or under the ice if you will), but for the most part it is just a regurgitation of Wayne’s many achievements and almost reads like a lifetime achievement award video. The information skips around, touches on elements and then moves on with little additional analysis or substantive counter points of view.

After Gretzky’s short time in St. Louis (that debacle was an interesting), Strachan chooses to focus more on Wayne’s involvement with the World Cup and Olympics (interesting and deserving of discussion) ignoring his time in New York.  As a Ranger fan I was looking forward to some glimpses into this tenure of his career.  The book’s only Ranger focus was on his last game and when he decided to retire.

Strachan’s close relationship with Gretzky also made the read slightly tedious with his constant praise and biased view.  I am surprised the title of the book wasn’t “Gretzky:  A March Towards Sainthood”.  Granted, the man was a great player, ambassador, and is seemingly a genuinely decent guy off the ice, but there were too many times when Strachan would blame the failures of other people if Gretzky didn’t achieve “greatness”, or ignore many of the contributions of other people in helping Gretzky when he did achieve “greatness”. I could practically hear Jan from the Brady bunch just screaming “Gretzky, Gretzky, Gretzky” instead of Marsha’s name.

I know it doesn’t seem like it but I did enjoy reading about Gretzky’s contribution to hockey, his many individual accomplishments, and his passion to help spread the love of the game.  However, I would have liked a more objective view with more insight from other players, coaches, and NHL personnel to give a more rounded perspective of certain times during his career.

title: Incompetence ...no longer a barrier for leading nations
text:
The commonality between the reigns of the late-capitalists; Teresa May, James Cameron, Michael Gove, Boris Johnson, Donald Trump, Jared Kushner (etc.) is:
1) These people are not leaders (Trump is a reality-show host, not a leader)
2) No base following them - May, Cameron, Gove, Johnson are the epitome of non-leaders without followings. There is noone lining up behind these "leaders."
3) No proven aptitude with any issue of importance.
4) Wealth - All recent PMs went to Eton, where they dreamt of the day they could grab this role; not, where they dreamt of any societal fixes. Likewise for Trump, who clearly can't even do the work of an 8th grade mind, but was failed-upward to please his moneybags daddy.
5) Political shallowness

And no shame.

Cameron's stunning, inept, unforced error (Brexit) shows he has facile, uncomprehending, untested, "above-it-all" Eton ideas about politics, which should deservedly remove him from public office for the rest of our lives. It's unfathomable that he has so little shame after his colossal screw-up, that he now foists this book on us, in an attempt at a political resurrection.

And each of these incompetent figures believe that because they have wealth, entitlement, and a complete lack of shame; that it's their turn to have power. This is what late-capitalism does to society ...whatever the cost. And each of them is a failed leader. Observe Trump's utter disinterest in addressing a plague that has caused the U.S. to be the breeding ground of the strongest strain of Covid-19, resulting in more deaths than were caused by WW1. The guy isn't going to be caught leading. He took the position for the grift. HIs own quote: "I take no responsibility for anything." And in the UK Boris Johnson ascends without an idea in his head and fumbles continually to voice a coherent view on any topic. Ah well, pass the baton to the next person of privilege who isn't a leader in any way.

Every capitalist's dream is to dance on democracy's corpse.

title: Unsatisfying ending...
text:
I don't really know how to even begin this review. I didn't dislike the book so much as I felt like it was incomplete and therefore, unsatisfying.

First, we have our sexy hero, Jake, who was bitten by a creature several years ago and now has to lock himself in a cage every time the moon is full because he is a werewolf and is afraid he'll harm or kill someone. Despite his "love 'em and leave 'em" approach to women, he's a good guy at heart. He's only ever been really drawn to one woman and it was after that one night they shared that he was bitten, and he's never seen her again.

Enter the new day camp coordinator, Josie, and of course, our hero's long lost obsession. She's got a tragic past, and is living the dreams of her deceased husband instead of her own. Turns out he was killed by some creature out in the wild four years ago. She hasn't gotten over it or beyond it and she's not looking for any kind of entanglement. Especially not with Jake, who tormented her in elementary school with snakes.

On the night the moon is full, she happens to stop by his office. Before he can make leave, the change is upon him. He tells her to lock him in his cage even as he is changing before her eyes. Her shock prevents her from locking the cage.....and it's a darn good thing, because another wolf pops up and seems intent on killing her. Our hero gets out of his cage, and engages the other wolf in a bloody fight.Josie passes out in the cage, having locked herself in for protection from both of them.

And thats it. Well, there is the struggle of their relationship, her coming to grips with his werewolf condition, his coming to grips with the fact that he might just love her. Some steamy sex. The fact that maybe Josie has been the target all along, not Jake and not her deceased husband. Unfortunately, the author never fully fleshes out this side of the story. Very little time is spent on the the attempt on her life, the mysterious wolf Jake fought, or really even anything to do with Jake's condition. The story ends with a short epilogue but it answers no questions (and I had several)and it didn't have the feel of a book that was being set up for a series.

For a paranormal romance, there isn't a whole lot of that aspect to the story. Jake's change is pretty much the extent of it. Hard core paranormal readers who like Laurell K Hamilton, Lora Leigh, Christine Feehan or Sherrilyn Kenyon will likely be disappointed with that. The relationship aspect of the story is well done and the love scenes are steamy. Unfortunately, there was just so much of the story missing that it took away from what was otherwise an entertaining read.

title: Good information in a bad package
text:
This book is a great resource for the volunteer lighting director who is learning through trial and error. There is scads of good information here, but the book is poorly edited and full of assumptions. A good example of this is page 33, "The warm tone in the key lights can be something like a Roscolux 02, Apollo 7050, Lee 162 or GAM 340..." If you knew ahead of time that these were gels placed in front of the bulb to color the light, this sentence makes sense.

If you have just enough information to be dangerous, then this book can take you to the next level. If you are a rank novice, get some help and keep dictionary.com and wikipedia.org handy.

title: Yawn...
text:
Sick Little Monkeys details the career of Ren & Stimpy’s eccentric and rebellious creator John Kricfalusi, who has been described by many as either an animation genius or a creative control freak. Mr. K always insisted on doing things his way whether his bosses agreed with him or not. The byproduct of his madness was cartoons that embraced toilet humor, bodily horror, and an uncaring attitude towards the youths they were marketed to. John K made many enemies during his time creating cartoons, but it begs the question of whether or not it was all worth it given the cult following Ren & Stimpy had and still has today.

I swore I would finish this book all the way through, but the repetitive and dull writing style makes it impossible to do so. Many of the same talking points were shoved down my throat over and over again whether it was John K’s rebelliousness, his inability to meet deadlines, his cartoons’ disgustingness, and worst of all, how “awful” and “disastrous” competing cartoons were. About the last item on that list, it would appear as if the author was taking sides with John K, but there were also times when he criticized the animator with as much venom as he did the competitors. If this book has a message, it was lost a long time ago the minute the writing style bored me to tears.

Perhaps the writing style could have been improved with some showing instead of telling. Instead of telling me how “bad” other cartoons are, show me what specifically made them that way. But of course, the author couldn’t do that without alienating the laymen of the animation world. Insider terms are used a lot in this book, which would have been fine if the book was marketed to professional animators as opposed to merely fans of Ren & Stimpy. I went into this read wanting to learn about the cartoon that made my childhood a happy time of my life. Instead all I got was technical drivel combined with a desert-dry writing style.

The closest the author ever got to showing instead of telling was pictures scattered here and there of John K’s sketches and storyboards. While pictures are always more effective at communicating than words, if that was all I wanted, I would have watched a movie. I wanted to read a book and use my imagination, an imagination guided by an author who’s supposed to be as entertaining as he is informative. I would have even settled for a graphic novel if that’s what the author really wanted. At least with a graphic novel, it wouldn’t feel like my eyes were being dragged across sandpaper. Now there’s a visual worthy of a Ren & Stimpy episode!

This was not a fun book to read and I can’t recommend it to my friends. I tried. I really tried. I wanted to like it and become a more educated person because of the reading experience. But no matter what, it just wouldn’t happen. I’d already known John K was a little off-color and this book does a good job of illustrating his depravity, but ultimately it’s not enough to keep my interest. I’m sorry, Mr. Komorowski, but this book gets a failing grade.

title: Slow, didn't warm to characters.
text:
It's the mid 8os. Soviet Galina leaves Leningrad and emigrates to Australia. It was a move that she meant to make with her mother, but after her mother's death, Galina decides to emigrate alone. She eventually lands in Melbourne Australia and once here she looks up Andrew Morrow, a young man she met (briefly) in the Soviet Union.
Andrew is a shy man, a mosaicist, and since he met Galina, he's thought of her often. Although he gave her his contact info when they met, he never really expected her to follow up.
Galina is drawn to Andrew and his parents Sylvie and Leonard--never guessing the secrets that lie beneath their seemingly comfortable marriage. There's a great irony here--Galina moves from a culture in which people must be careful and hide so much from public scrutiny when it comes to their views, and here in Australia people also hoard secrets--afraid to tell the truth,
I found the book to be slow and while the plot (and its connections about being true to oneself) are good, I never warmed to the characters in spite of the dilemmas they face.

title: 3 Stars with an Anchor.  2.5 actually.
text:
I enjoy Lescroart's novels. They remind me a bit of Harlan Coben with a West Coast feel. The novel reads easy and I anticipated a great ending. We've got dishonest politicians, a stone-cold killer in witness protection, human trafficking, and the usual suspects. A good cast of characters that.....fizzle. The trial antics are deeply dissatisfying, there is no real i.d. on the killer, the matron with a gun....comes from almost nowhere. Characters disappear, sometimes with a rationale, sometimes not.

The novel relies significantly on the backstory (The First Law?) with many references to prior acts. That's fine if you've read the prior novel within your recent memory, but it's a frustrating experience if it has been awhile. New readers will get lost.

And now, the worst part: for the quality of the novel, the price is waaaaaay to high. I don't mind paying $12 for a Tier1 e-book. This novel didn't make the cut, Ophelia or otherwise.

title: Rare text - great - but terrible print quality for the price
text:
I’m grateful to Kessinger for making these rare texts available. 5 stars for doing that.
BUT …
The print quality and typeset are so poor the book is difficult to read.
Yes, scanners with software to render print characters from scanned images are expensive. Hiring someone to actually re-type the text might be expensive.
In some cases preserving the original type is of historical value.
In this case - “historical value” is no excuse. This book is a poor quality scan slapped into a modern book with no thought given to readability.
The margins are wonky. Outside margins are HUGE while inside margins are so narrow the print almost goes into the fold. Bottom margin is so small the text runs to the very bottom of the page. The pages don’t match - looking across a spread one side is higher than the other.
Seriously I could - and have - done better with a xerox machine.
The book is needlessly large and heavy. Obviously the original book was long and narrow and they’ve jammed this into a modern size that wastes a lot of space on those huge outside margins.
If the book cost less I would accept the poor quality happily.
But at nearly $40?
It should have been typeset with proper margins and better quality print. This looks like something home made using a very old very cheap scanner by someone who couldn’t care less if anyone is actually reading the book.

title: A Typical Libertarian Manifesto  ( with a trust fund)
text:
Much of the book is taken up by an exhaustive listing of how the "regulatory state" has taken away our liberty. This is sadly true but it has been presented in earlier and more interesting works such as Philip K Howard's "the Death of Common Sense".
Murray's only original idea is legal defense fund for individuals and business owners who fall prey to the capricious regulatory system. This is a great idea and if the book ended there it would have been a valuable pamphlet.
However Murray goes on to present a (very interesting) description of US demographics starting with the founding in the early 1600s, which he then uses to support the idea that America is best when it is diverse - in the sense of everyone letting everyone else do whatever they want. Here is where the classic libertarian ideology slyly presents itself. While carefully avoiding direct statement he proposes that the liberal "blue" urban areas be allowed to embrace homosexual marriage and legalized drugs while the conservative "red" counties not be forced to comply. He repeatedly states that everyone be allowed to live "as they see fit". This is his definition of Liberty.
Murray's highest praise is for the internet which allows freedom of choice in consumption and expression of ideas. Here also the amoral libertarian view becomes obvious. He does not take into account a human nature that often chooses what is bad. The first growth sectors of the internet marketplace were gambling and pornography, and the internet "marketplace of ideas" is recruiting Jihadis from American suburbs.
At one point he makes a remark about the poor behavior of some students in American schools and how common sense would dictate that these students be expelled so that others can learn in a safe environment.. While trying to make a point about free choice Murray unconsciously reveals the central problem with American society - that while we can usually identify what is bad( crime and violence), we are increasingly losing the ability to agree about what is GOOD,

title: This one was disappointing
text: I've read all the Railway Detective books to this point, and really enjoyed most of them, but this one was disappointing.  The side stories just weren't that interesting, and the end was almost hurried and totally anticlimactic -- it felt rushed and wrong.  There could have been a way better and more interesting killer with better reasons, along with an ending that had you on the edge of your seat -- but neither were there this time.  We never know who the second woman is in one of the subplots, and there are other loose ends as well.  The author must have been in a hurry to get this one out, or just at a more distracting time in his life.  Still, most other books in this series have been really enjoyable, and I'll continue with the series.

title: Excerpt from Whisker's larger work "Arms Makers of Pennsylvania", not as thorough as I thought.
text: As a research reference, the book is specific to Huntingdon County, PA gunsmiths.  This book appears to be an excerpt of J. B. Whisker's "Arms Makers of Pennsylvania".  It doesn't summarize the specific characteristics of long rifles made in Huntingdon County or the "Huntingdon County School" of gun making.  I found the information presented about the gunsmith I researched to be totally inaccurate - wrong date of birth, wrong initials, wrong family, etc.  I received more accurate information from the Huntingdon County Historical Society.  Generally, the information presented in this book is ok, but do your own research to verify and/or validate the information you need.

title: Disappointingly difficult to read - and the content is disjointed
text:
It saddens me that I cannot award this effort more than 3 stars. There is no question that the author is making a sincere, earnest attempt to produce a useful beginner's instructional manual for Artisteer, a specialty program for web template creation that has a moderate learning curve.

Unfortunately English is not Jakub Sanecki's first language and Packt Publishing did not provide extensive editing, with particular attention to syntax and composition.

The result is prose that simply doesn't flow well. The language is clunky and difficult to read. Worse is that the author's approach is disjointed, jumping from subject to subject. This approach frequently left me confused. The author is clearly trying to take this moderately complex application and render it accessible to a new user. The Artisteer manual itself will accomplish that purpose - but it will take several careful readings and a lot of experimentation.

Sanecki's book is simply difficult to read. For example: "Shapes are graphic objects (in the form of geometric figures) that you can insert into the header." The parenthetical that shapes are "geometric figures" is redundant and superfluous considering that there are two illustrations depicting shapes on the facing page. The use of illustrations is also problematic. They are straight screenshots, occasionally with a single line caption below. The illustrations could have been made vastly more effective by providing numbered callouts describing the various operations being discussed.

There are valuable and helpful hints and tips scattered throughout, but their presence does not compensate for the language and lack of editing. There are also glaring omissions, such as not pointing out that you cannot directly create a two-line headline in a title block, a big issue for many, including me. You have to modify the code outside of Artisteer.

Overall, the author has clearly made an effort to help the user new to Artisteer. But considering the high cost for this relatively thin book, one might be better advised to make their way through the Artisteer manual - twice if necessary - and try things out along the way.

Jerry

title: Boring
text:
This is easily the most boring book I ever attempted to read. I wasted one evening trying to like it. I even committed the cardinal sin of book reading by skipping ahead to see if it improved over time. No such luck. It was consigned to "the thrift store basket" the next morning (today as a matter of fact). I was very disappointed as I had read "The Omnivores Dilemma" by the same author and found it wonderfully interesting and thought provoking and was looking for more of the same.

This book is not about gardening. It is about the authors philosophy regarding gardening and how that developed along with his garden. This book is extremely cerebral. Too highbrow for my tastes. I was hoping for an amusing anecdotal tale of how a beginning gardener battled the forces of evil (pests,weeds and soil) in New England ground that had never seen a real garden before.

Instead, for example, I was treated to pages upon pages of philosophical discussion of the place of Lawn in Americas cultural and societal structure and how how our Lawn differs from that of the English in terms of fenced and walled vs not fenced and not walled and the reason for Americas break from the English method-revolt. Not to mention the place, or lack thereof, of Lawn in the garden schema.

We are similarly treated to more pages regarding the philosophy of eliminating pests in the garden be they flora or fauna. Not to mention the sexual enticement of the Rose-but not any rose-only a old world rose will do-not a ridiculous modern hybrid tea rose. Really?

However other reviews indicate that other people like it. And, according to the book cover, it is listed as being among some horticultural society's 75 most important gardening books of all time. So what do I know.

I do know one thing. That buying books on line because they "sound good" cannot take the place of actually looking at them in a real bookstore. I had learned the hard way that one only buys cookbooks at a real book store. Because I had liked the first work I had read from this Author so well I thought I would enjoy any of his other books and that I would not have to look at them first. Wrong!

title: A Political Thriller without the Thrill
text:
President Charlotte Kramer has just won reelection for a second term after breaking from tradition and choosing a member of the opposition party as her vice presidential running mate instead of the incumbent from her first term. Now only weeks into her term, she and others are noticing some problems with Tara Meyers, the new vice president. She's not as focused on the policies and issues as she needs to be, is canceling appearances, and working from home frequently. Staffers are starting to ask questions, and members of the press are digging for answers.

The premise of this near-future political thriller was an interesting one, tracing the ripple effects of a possibly impaired elected member of the federal government and how that could spawn investigations, grand juries, and special councils that impact not only the politician in question but the administration itself. Unfortunately the execution of the idea was not handled in such a way that did it justice.

Much of the punch of the story is removed in the first few pages of the book when Tara Meyers's household goods are being packed and moved from the vice president's official residence. So the reader already knows the outcome, just not whether her removal from the office was voluntary or forced. After that, most of the book becomes a look back at how things got to that point and removes the suspense from the story.

The focus of much of the book is centered around the vice president's senior adviser, Dale Smith. Again since the final outcome is already known by the reader, Dale's observations and concerns seem less of a shock, as do those of all the other White House characters and members of the press and Congress.

Another failing of the book was the big build up of the congressional battles being faced by the president on account of her vice presidential choice, yet the reader is not given the payoff of her testimony to stave off impeachment proceedings or that of others' testimony in grand jury hearings. As a result, the story ends in more of a fizzle than the big bang that the situation would inspire. The inside, dramatic details are omitted leaving the reader with an unsatisfying experience. The outcome was revealed from the beginning, so there is not even a mystery left to fall back on.

Not recommended.

title: The statistics and facts stated in this book should not be overlooked.
text:
I would probably give this book 3.5 stars if I could. It's definitely somewhere in between 3 and 4 stars.

I picked up this book because I happed to agree with the author. As anyone in Corporate America knows these days, leading or managing people isn't what it used to be - even 10 years ago. Things have changed - and continue to change drastically - as global economy takes over more and more everyday. Personally, I am on the fence about this global economy. On one hand, I think it's good that goods & services can be traded around the world - it invites more competition and provide people with goods & services that they might not have otherwise. On the other hand, it doesn't do much for job growth, particularily in the U.S. where trade laws remain unprotected, if looking at it from a labor workers' point of view. But that's what great about this book - it literally loads you with facts about countries, the population of the world overall, different types of economies (Capitalism, Communism, Socialism), and provides you with the good & bad of each, allowing you to make up your own mind about if the end of power is a step forward or a step backward.

Some of the reviews state that this reads like a textbook - and it does. However, the facts that were researched in this book cannot be dismissed, as the author has obviously completed some SERIOUS fact-checking & researching. And, the fact that a lot of what he says in the book (written in 2006), has actually come to fruition in 2015. I think as most people read this book they will agree with the facts that the author points out, especially if your a leader or someone in management.

I will disagree with a quote on the back cover that states that the book "will change my views on how I see and read the news". This is not a true fact. As one should realize by now, most of the news station broadcasts are done so by corporations that own them, so people should know that the news is already biased, so I'm not quite sure why one would think that from reading this book.

Overall, it's a good read with some fascinating statistics in it. It's definitely a slower read, as it does read like a textbook at times. Although the book is a small paperback. I managed to finish it in 4 days.

title: Court Room Drama
text:
A free physical book from BookishFirst in exchange for an honest review.

I really enjoyed this book. I was entertained throughout and wanted to know more.
The story is told from multiple perspectives and from multiple timelines. This worked for the story and kept it interesting.

There were two big reveals that you knew were driving this story, and one reveal that was needed to kind of tie them together that was not necessarily a given. I really enjoyed the first reveal, it was the last reveal that made this book from four stars to only three. Maybe I do not understand politics enough to know what would count as a huge drama? Or this was just a little to flat for the story and it needed something just a little bit bigger.

title: Misleading.  Too much politics and not enough financial data
text:
Since this author is a noted financial guru, I was curious to know his take on the potential crash of the US dollar. Unfortunately, I got too little of the author's financial expertise and too much of the author's opinions on politics, diet, and energy.

The book starts off good with some well written financial history and some good insight by the author. However, most of the book is the author's personal views with a little financial information sprinkled in. I agreed with the author on several of his points but I found myself wanting more financial data.

If you're looking for a good financial book about the crash of the US dollar this is not it.

title: I only purchased this book as a collectors item. ...
text: I only purchased this book as a collectors item.  It is the only book of which I am aware to be printed using the Shavian alphabet and type font.  George Bernard Shaw had an interest in rationalizing the English language such that each letter or letter combination would be pronounced in the same way every time it is used.  This required the invention of a new 40-character alphabet with each letter sounded only one way. Shaw's will and trust made provision for the printing of this book.

title: Uninteresting
text:
Like others reviewing this book, I am mystified why it is touted as a mystery. It's a tale of a squabbling family told in the first person by Jack, or Randle as he is now calling himself. Randle has recently been released from prison but he does not seem to be on parole because he drops everything and travels across state lines to his mother's bedside when she has a heart attack. There he finds her near death, malnourished and with bedsores. His brother and family who live nearby appear to be neglecting mom.

Randle is not an interesting guy, his siblings and their families are unpleasant, the interpersonal relationships are toxic, and someone might have been pushing mom to the edge of the cliff. I found the first person narrative irritating and found nothing of interest in the story. I did not finish the book.

I received a review copy of "The Undiscovered Country" by Mike Nemeth (Morgan James Fiction) directly from the publisher.

There's a great source on advice for a lasting marriage. Her advice on fidelity was also odd, a woman can cheat on her spouse one time, but no way in hell can a man cheat ever! WHAT??? Buy Brandi Glanville's book instead. Brandi, unlike Kyle, is witty, entertaining, and her book is refreshingly funny and honest.

text: While this book take place in the same universe of the first one, and contains two characters who were part of that book, it has little to nothing to do with the Wayfarer and its crew. The one crew member involved is Lovey, the AI, only in her new, highly illegal form in a mobile body (referred to as a kit throughout), and Pepper, a modder who can fix just about anything, and who was a friend of two of the characters in the ...small angry planet... book. It follows Pepper from age 10 when she escapes from a segregated life as one of a class of servers on a rather awful planet through her ability to get off said planet with the help of an AI and a scrapped 'lunar' module  to find a new life for herself and her friend. The book is segmented between the back story of Pepper's growing up and escaping and the AI trying to learn to adjust to her new life as a human. I was not thrilled. Neither story was sufficiently engrossing to keep me reading it (I skipped pages throughout). Except for the language, this would likely be a YA story, but it might be slightly boring even for them. I tried to like it, but I expected to read more about the Wayfarer and crew, and that just wasn't on offer. I am hopeful the 3rd book will be better.

title: "The stiffs. The corpses. In the morgue. They've come back to life."
text:
"Handling the Undead" is a zombie book. But not the typical gory, horrendous BRAAAAAAINSSSS-craving type. Instead John Ajvinde Lindquist slowly weaves together an intelligent, philosophical look at what would happen if the dead were to unnaturally rise from their graves... and the only flaw is that the middle section of the book is so SLOW.

Something strange is happening in Stockholm -- the weather is oppressive, electrical glitches are everywhere, and everybody has a headache.

But when the strange conditions vanish, everybody who has died within the last two months rises from the morgue, funeral homes, and even their coffins. The "reliving" wander back to their old homes, mute and seemingly unaware, shocking their loved ones. And of course, the government quickly rounds them up and confines them, until they can be sure what dangers the "reliving" might pose.

In the days that follow, Lindqvist follows five people whose loved ones have come back -- a comedian sunk deep in denial about his wife being gone, a wannabe-rebel teen, a grandfather and a young mother trying to help her undead son "recover," and a widow who believes that she has a mission from the Virgin Mary. But something else is approaching Stockholm, bringing unexpected effects in its wake.

"Handling the Undead" doesn't really focus on the zombies themselves. Instead, Lindqvist conjures up a simple scenario, and examines how people would react to it -- we see hysteria, suicide, denial, dismissal, religious fervor, and a delusional belief that the zombies can simply go back to their old lives. And he brings up a number of philosophical questions with no easy answers.

The biggest problem with this book is that it should have been much smaller. Lindqvist spends most of the book's middle section spinning his wheels, with nothing really happening. And we never really find out WHY the dead rose, just that it is somehow an error.

Fortunately the beginning and ending are filled with subtle, creeping psychological horror (the whole scene with the grotesque drowned zombie is nauseating), as well as the painful scene where David and Magnus meet Eva again. And there's an exquisite metaphysical edge, which implies that there's more out there than just zombies -- think an elusive, benevolent figure with fishhook fingertips.

Lindqvist also fleshes out his characters beautifully, giving each one a backstory that shapes their current reactions. And he handles each one with compassion, even if they're delusional or twerpy. Among the best are David (desperately clinging to hope and unable to grieve), Flora (a rather annoying a teen who thinks she's an iconoclast), and Anna (whose son Elias has "come back") -- and even some of the zombies show a glimmer of personality.

"Handling the Undead" is a deeply flawed book -- the entire middle section is bogged down. Yet it's still a beautiful, affecting read.

title: Too Much Knowledge is Insufficient
text:
“The Age of EM: Work, Love, and Life When Robots Rule the Earth, is Robin Hanson’s vision of what will happen when humans are able to create the equivalent of the human brain complete with the full spectrum of rational and emotional intelligence. A heavily footnoted volume, Hanson wants to legitimize his interpretation of the past history of human development and continue that transition as robot intelligence rises to the next evolutionary level and humans essentially fade into a peripheral existence.

One of the positives of this volume is that the author has been willing to engage with his critics as evidenced by a number of his responses to postings to the reviews on the Amazon.com website. The concerning issue is the author’s response to the 150 or so critics that he cites, and dismisses, in the book, primarily, with the rationale that most, supposedly colleagues, whom he believes are more interested in history, are seemingly indifferent to the “future”, at least the far future where computers are able to emulate humans, as suggested by the title, The Age of EM.

Hanson wants to legitimize his analysis or predictions by his adoption of a heavily footnoted, academic style, while simultaneously dismissing others who have adopted a narrative often cast in the genre of science fiction. What he fails to understand, and denies leveraging, is that much of the analysis of artifacts and scientific research are also woven into “stories”. In fact, Yuval Harari’s “Sapiens” makes the strong case that what is responsible for human progress is language and the ability to tell “stories”.

Hanson has a strong history of research and development in the hard sciences and information technology and if he had focused that knowledge to take the global research and carefully develop a scenario to show the pathway to machines that can emulate human brains one would have an understanding of the current and needed directions to a promised realization. But, one suspects that such a book would have limited readership, and only within a select community. This is clear where the author makes the distinction between machine emulations and what he sees as a weaker research arena, artificial intelligence which, today, is in ascendance and which has captured the imagination across academic disciplines and the commercial sector, globally.

The author’s intellectual path took an orthogonal turn into the social sciences, particularly, economics. Herein lies the fatal flaw in the book’s thesis. Unlike fiction, particularly science fiction, the book does not have a cohesive story, with the exception that the volume is written from and within a western cultural paradigm with seemingly a conventional neoclassical economic perspective. The book creates a very sketchy evolutionary model from foraging to farming to industrialization. And there it stops. It is a standard western rendering. While there are copious references, they are selective and many of these taken within their academic frame are, themselves, not necessarily without their own controversies and accepted interpretations.

More importantly, in an age of “EM” with the wired equivalent of Teilhard de Chardin’s Noosphere, it is questionable whether that cultural mold can hold. In fact, in an academic environment characterized by ever narrowing disciplinary focus, scholars may less readily accept the selective citations as rationales.

Hanson eschews the idea of fictional stories, yet he uses this model to selectively pick potential traits of his EM’s in some distant future, one that looks much like North America or Europe with its current culture and economy. It is as if all the work in creating EM’s will yield a 1:1 socioeconomic and personality matching of the current middle class and that world is the future. Hanson seems to believe that by playing the academic and selectively, but extensively, documenting his narrative that it avoids the idea that his “story” takes credence over the metaphorical world relegated to science fiction, at least in validating his concept of what EM’s will be and how they will function in the evolution beyond our current industrial models.

The fatal flaw is trying to treat a complex bio/physical/socio/economic system with a rational/scientific model. Hold constant all variables except the one under investigation. In this case, humans create EM’s and then they are written into fringe obscurity devoid of any advancement since EM’s fulfill those niches in both the mundane and the creative, except for leisure. Somehow that which drives humans to create EM’s and the world up to the manifestation of EM’s is exorcized. Somehow the current economic models now under evolutionary pressure by what has been defined as heterodox thinking, and tied to the growing environmental concerns with global warming and many other issues, remain frozen until EM’s with their superior processing and advanced physical capabilities reach consciousness.

While Hanson tries to inject some emotion into the EM’s, since they are emulations of the human brain, his one-dimensional focus on pleasure with sexual relations, artificially induced in electromechanical systems, fails. He, like many of those he criticizes, fails to release the single vision constraints by assuming that all EM’s, except for “work” have the same socio/cultural homogeneity. Issues such as minority rights, religious differences and global cultural tensions across individual and geo/political boundaries disappear, probably because humans have become socio/political eunuchs or perhaps, as in the movie, The Matrix, all are fed the “blue pill” in their diets and live in a dream world.

Rudy Rucker is another scientist who has crossed the academic boundaries but, unlike Hanson, has, also, written in the science fiction genre. His substantive work, The Ware Tetrology, carries EM’s into the time when they inhabit biological forms resembling humans and who eventually seek citizenship along side of humans. Rucker, Stephenson in his “Diamond Age”, David Brin in the Hanson cited “Kiln People” and a number of science fiction writers have taken, as has Hanson, that EM’s will be constructed. But they have removed the social constraints.

In many ways Hanson has adopted the same conservative idea of the distant future of his critics, by constraining his “story” to that which can be footnoted or which can be molded within the current collegial fabrications. This review is being written in 2016 during the current presidential race in the United States. One understands the potential global ramifications at a time when the Middle East is in the midst of violent culture and political discord.

Similarly, the issues resulting from the 2008 financial meltdown have not been resolved and the international finance communities are also in a quandary. One can readily understand why it may not be thinking about the future that is the problem, but rather it’s the cognitive dissonance in the attempt to academically rationalize this analysis into its reductionist format.
